Untidy, full of Greeks, Ishmaelites, cats, Italians,\r\n      tomatoes, restaurants, organs, coloured stuffs, queer names,\r\n      people looking out of upper windows, it dwells remote from the\r\n      British Body Politic. Yet has it haphazard proprietary instincts\r\n      of its own, and a certain possessive prosperity which keeps its\r\n      rents up when those of other quarters go down. For long years\r\n      Soames\xe2\x80\x99 acquaintanceship with Soho had been confined to its\r\n      Western bastion, Wardour Street. Many bargains had he picked up\r\n      there. Even during those seven years at Brighton after Bosinney\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      death and Irene\xe2\x80\x99s flight, he had bought treasures there\r\n      sometimes, though he had no place to put them; for when the\r\n      conviction that his wife had gone for good at last became firm\r\n      within him, he had caused a board to be put up in Montpellier\r\n      Square:\r\n\r\n      FOR SALE\r\n      THE LEASE OF THIS DESIRABLE RESIDENCE\r\n      Enquire of Messrs. Lesson and Tukes, Court Street, Belgravia.\r\n\r\n      It had sold within a week\xe2\x80\x94that desirable residence, in the shadow\r\n      of whose perfection a man and a woman had eaten their hearts out.\r\n\r\n      Of a misty January evening, just before the board was taken down,\r\n      Soames had gone there once more, and stood against the Square\r\n      railings, looking at its unlighted windows, chewing the cud of\r\n      possessive memories which had turned so bitter in the mouth. Why\r\n      had she never loved him? Why? She had been given all she had\r\n      wanted, and in return had given him, for three long years, all he\r\n      had wanted\xe2\x80\x94except, indeed, her heart. He had uttered a little\r\n      involuntary groan, and a passing policeman had glanced\r\n      suspiciously at him who no longer possessed the right to enter\r\n      that green door with the carved brass knocker beneath the board\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cFor Sale!\xe2\x80\x9d A choking sensation had attacked his throat, and he\r\n      had hurried away into the mist. That evening he had gone to\r\n      Brighton to live....\r\n\r\n      Approaching Malta Street, Soho, and the Restaurant Bretagne,\r\n      where Annette would be drooping her pretty shoulders over her\r\n      accounts, Soames thought with wonder of those seven years at\r\n      Brighton. How had he managed to go on so long in that town devoid\r\n      of the scent of sweetpeas, where he had not even space to put his\r\n      treasures? True, those had been years with no time at all for\r\n      looking at them\xe2\x80\x94years of almost passionate money-making, during\r\n      which Forsyte, Bustard and Forsyte had become solicitors to more\r\n      limited Companies than they could properly attend to. Up to the\r\n      City of a morning in a Pullman car, down from the City of an\r\n      evening in a Pullman car. Law papers again after dinner, then the\r\n      sleep of the tired, and up again next morning. Saturday to Monday\r\n      was spent at his Club in town\xe2\x80\x94curious reversal of customary\r\n      procedure, based on the deep and careful instinct that while\r\n      working so hard he needed sea air to and from the station twice a\r\n      day, and while resting must indulge his domestic affections. The\r\n      Sunday visit to his family in Park Lane, to Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s, and to\r\n      Green Street; the occasional visits elsewhere had seemed to him\r\n      as necessary to health as sea air on weekdays. Even since his\r\n      migration to Mapledurham he had maintained those habits until\xe2\x80\x94he\r\n      had known Annette.\r\n\r\n      Whether Annette had produced the revolution in his outlook, or\r\n      that outlook had produced Annette, he knew no more than we know\r\n      where a circle begins. It was intricate and deeply involved with\r\n      the growing consciousness that property without anyone to leave\r\n      it to is the negation of true Forsyteism. To have an heir, some\r\n      continuance of self, who would begin where he left off\xe2\x80\x94ensure, in\r\n      fact, that he would not leave off\xe2\x80\x94had quite obsessed him for the\r\n      last year and more. After buying a bit of Wedgwood one evening in\r\n      April, he had dropped into Malta Street to look at a house of his\r\n      father\xe2\x80\x99s which had been turned into a restaurant\xe2\x80\x94a risky\r\n      proceeding, and one not quite in accordance with the terms of the\r\n      lease. He had stared for a little at the outside painted a good\r\n      cream colour, with two peacock-blue tubs containing little\r\n      bay-trees in a recessed doorway\xe2\x80\x94and at the words \xe2\x80\x9cRestaurant\r\n      Bretagne\xe2\x80\x9d above them in gold letters, rather favourably\r\n      impressed. Entering, he had noticed that several people were\r\n      already seated at little round green tables with little pots of\r\n      fresh flowers on them and Brittany-ware plates, and had asked of\r\n      a trim waitress to see the proprietor. They had shown him into a\r\n      back room, where a girl was sitting at a simple bureau covered\r\n      with papers, and a small round, table was laid for two. The\r\n      impression of cleanliness, order, and good taste was confirmed\r\n      when the girl got up, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cYou wish to see _Maman,\r\n      Monsieur?_\xe2\x80\x9d in a broken accent.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d Soames had answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI represent your landlord; in fact,\r\n      I\xe2\x80\x99m his son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you sit down, sir, please? Tell _Maman_ to come to this\r\n      gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He was pleased that the girl seemed impressed, because it showed\r\n      business instinct; and suddenly he noticed that she was\r\n      remarkably pretty\xe2\x80\x94so remarkably pretty that his eyes found a\r\n      difficulty in leaving her face. When she moved to put a chair for\r\n      him, she swayed in a curious subtle way, as if she had been put\r\n      together by someone with a special secret skill; and her face and\r\n      neck, which was a little bared, looked as fresh as if they had\r\n      been sprayed with dew. Probably at this moment Soames decided\r\n      that the lease had not been violated; though to himself and his\r\n      father he based the decision on the efficiency of those illicit\r\n      adaptations in the building, on the signs of prosperity, and the\r\n      obvious business capacity of Madame Lamotte. He did not, however,\r\n      neglect to leave certain matters to future consideration, which\r\n      had necessitated further visits, so that the little back room had\r\n      become quite accustomed to his spare, not unsolid, but\r\n      unobtrusive figure, and his pale, chinny face with clipped\r\n      moustache and dark hair not yet grizzling at the sides.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c_Un Monsieur tr\xc3\xa8s distingu\xc3\xa9_,\xe2\x80\x9d Madame Lamotte found him; and\r\n      presently, \xe2\x80\x9c_Tr\xc3\xa8s amical, tr\xc3\xa8s gentil_,\xe2\x80\x9d watching his eyes upon\r\n      her daughter.\r\n\r\n      She was one of those generously built, fine-faced, dark-haired\r\n      Frenchwomen, whose every action and tone of voice inspire perfect\r\n      confidence in the thoroughness of their domestic tastes, their\r\n      knowledge of cooking, and the careful increase of their bank\r\n      balances.\r\n\r\n      After those visits to the Restaurant Bretagne began, other visits\r\n      ceased\xe2\x80\x94without, indeed, any definite decision, for Soames, like\r\n      all Forsytes, and the great majority of their countrymen, was a\r\n      born empiricist. But it was this change in his mode of life which\r\n      had gradually made him so definitely conscious that he desired to\r\n      alter his condition from that of the unmarried married man to\r\n      that of the married man remarried.\r\n\r\n      Turning into Malta Street on this evening of early October, 1899,\r\n      he bought a paper to see if there were any after-development of\r\n      the Dreyfus case\xe2\x80\x94a question which he had always found useful in\r\n      making closer acquaintanceship with Madame Lamotte and her\r\n      daughter, who were Catholic and anti-Dreyfusard.\r\n\r\n      Scanning those columns, Soames found nothing French, but noticed\r\n      a general fall on the Stock Exchange and an ominous leader about\r\n      the Transvaal. He entered, thinking: \xe2\x80\x9cWar\xe2\x80\x99s a certainty. I shall\r\n      sell my consols.\xe2\x80\x9d Not that he had many, personally, the rate of\r\n      interest was too wretched; but he should advise his\r\n      Companies\xe2\x80\x94consols would assuredly go down. A look, as he passed\r\n      the doorways of the restaurant, assured him that business was\r\n      good as ever, and this, which in April would have pleased him,\r\n      now gave him a certain uneasiness. If the steps which he had to\r\n      take ended in his marrying Annette, he would rather see her\r\n      mother safely back in France, a move to which the prosperity of\r\n      the Restaurant Bretagne might become an obstacle. He would have\r\n      to buy them out, of course, for French people only came to\r\n      England to make money; and it would mean a higher price. And then\r\n      that peculiar sweet sensation at the back of his throat, and a\r\n      slight thumping about the heart, which he always experienced at\r\n      the door of the little room, prevented his thinking how much it\r\n      would cost.\r\n\r\n      Going in, he was conscious of an abundant black skirt vanishing\r\n      through the door into the restaurant, and of Annette with her\r\n      hands up to her hair. It was the attitude in which of all others\r\n      he admired her\xe2\x80\x94so beautifully straight and rounded and supple.\r\n      And he said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI just came in to talk to your mother about pulling down that\r\n      partition. No, don\xe2\x80\x99t call her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c_Monsieur_ will have supper with us? It will be ready in ten\r\n      minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d Soames, who still held her hand, was overcome by an\r\n      impulse which surprised him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou look so pretty to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cso very pretty. Do you\r\n      know how pretty you look, Annette?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette withdrew her hand, and blushed. \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur is very good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNot a bit good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, and sat down gloomily.\r\n\r\n      Annette made a little expressive gesture with her hands; a smile\r\n      was crinkling her red lips untouched by salve.\r\n\r\n      And, looking at those lips, Soames said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAre you happy over here, or do you want to go back to France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh, I like London. Paris, of course. But London is better than\r\n      Orleans, and the English country is so beautiful. I have been to\r\n      Richmond last Sunday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames went through a moment of calculating struggle.\r\n      Mapledurham! Dared he? After all, dared he go so far as that, and\r\n      show her what there was to look forward to! Still! Down there one\r\n      could say things. In this room it was impossible.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI want you and your mother,\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly, \xe2\x80\x9cto come for the\r\n      afternoon next Sunday. My house is on the river, it\xe2\x80\x99s not too\r\n      late in this weather; and I can show you some good pictures. What\r\n      do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette clasped her hands.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt will be lovelee. The river is so beautiful\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s understood, then. I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask Madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He need say no more to her this evening, and risk giving himself\r\n      away. But had he not already said too much? Did one ask\r\n      restaurant proprietors with pretty daughters down to one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      country house without design? Madame Lamotte would see, if\r\n      Annette didn\xe2\x80\x99t. Well! there was not much that Madame did not see.\r\n      Besides, this was the second time he had stayed to supper with\r\n      them; he owed them hospitality.\r\n\r\n      Walking home towards Park Lane\xe2\x80\x94for he was staying at his\r\n      father\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94with the impression of Annette\xe2\x80\x99s soft clever hand within\r\n      his own, his thoughts were pleasant, slightly sensual, rather\r\n      puzzled. Take steps! What steps? How? Dirty linen washed in\r\n      public? Pah! With his reputation for sagacity, for\r\n      far-sightedness and the clever extrication of others, he, who\r\n      stood for proprietary interests, to become the plaything of that\r\n      Law of which he was a pillar! There was something revolting in\r\n      the thought! Winifred\xe2\x80\x99s affair was bad enough! To have a double\r\n      dose of publicity in the family! Would not a liaison be better\r\n      than that\xe2\x80\x94a liaison, and a son he could adopt? But dark, solid,\r\n      watchful, Madame Lamotte blocked the avenue of that vision. No!\r\n      that would not work. It was not as if Annette could have a real\r\n      passion for him; one could not expect that at his age. If her\r\n      mother wished, if the worldly advantage were manifestly\r\n      great\xe2\x80\x94perhaps! If not, refusal would be certain. Besides, he\r\n      thought: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not a villain. I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to hurt her; and I\r\n      don\xe2\x80\x99t want anything underhand. But I do want her, and I want a\r\n      son! There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing for it but divorce\xe2\x80\x94somehow\xe2\x80\x94anyhow\xe2\x80\x94divorce!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      Under the shadow of the plane-trees, in the lamplight, he passed\r\n      slowly along the railings of the Green Park. Mist clung there\r\n      among the bluish tree shapes, beyond range of the lamps. How many\r\n      hundred times he had walked past those trees from his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      house in Park Lane, when he was quite a young man; or from his\r\n      own house in Montpellier Square in those four years of married\r\n      life! And, to-night, making up his mind to free himself if he\r\n      could of that long useless marriage tie, he took a fancy to walk\r\n      on, in at Hyde Park Corner, out at Knightsbridge Gate, just as he\r\n      used to when going home to Irene in the old days. What could she\r\n      be like now?\xe2\x80\x94how had she passed the years since he last saw her,\r\n      twelve years in all, seven already since Uncle Jolyon left her\r\n      that money? Was she still beautiful? Would he know her if he saw\r\n      her? \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve not changed much,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; \xe2\x80\x9cI expect she has. She\r\n      made me suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d He remembered suddenly one night, the first on\r\n      which he went out to dinner alone\xe2\x80\x94an old Malburian dinner\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n      first year of their marriage. With what eagerness he had hurried\r\n      back; and, entering softly as a cat, had heard her playing.\r\n      Opening the drawing-room door noiselessly, he had stood watching\r\n      the expression on her face, different from any he knew, so much\r\n      more open, so confiding, as though to her music she was giving a\r\n      heart he had never seen. And he remembered how she stopped and\r\n      looked round, how her face changed back to that which he did\r\n      know, and what an icy shiver had gone through him, for all that\r\n      the next moment he was fondling her shoulders. Yes, she had made\r\n      him suffer! Divorce! It seemed ridiculous, after all these years\r\n      of utter separation! But it would have to be. No other way! \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\n      question,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought with sudden realism, \xe2\x80\x9cis\xe2\x80\x94which of us? She\r\n      or me? She deserted me. She ought to pay for it. There\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\n      someone, I suppose.\xe2\x80\x9d Involuntarily he uttered a little snarling\r\n      sound, and, turning, made his way back to Park Lane.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER V JAMES SEES VISIONS\r\n\r\n\r\n      The butler himself opened the door, and closing it softly,\r\n      detained Soames on the inner mat.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThe master\xe2\x80\x99s poorly, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cHe wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t go to bed\r\n      till you came in. He\xe2\x80\x99s still in the diningroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames responded in the hushed tone to which the house was now\r\n      accustomed.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with him, Warmson?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNervous, sir, I think. The mistress has just gone\r\n      up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames hung his hat on a mahogany stag\xe2\x80\x99s-horn.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right, Warmson, you can go to bed; I\xe2\x80\x99ll take him up myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      And he passed into the dining-room.\r\n\r\n      James was sitting before the fire, in a big armchair, with a\r\n      camel-hair shawl, very light and warm, over his frock-coated\r\n      shoulders, on to which his long white whiskers drooped. At\r\n      eighty-eight he was still organically sound, but suffering\r\n      terribly from the thought that no one ever told him anything. It\r\n      is, indeed, doubtful how he had become aware that Roger was being\r\n      buried that day, for Emily had kept it from him. She was always\r\n      keeping things from him. Emily was only seventy! James had a\r\n      grudge against his wife\xe2\x80\x99s youth. He felt sometimes that he would\r\n      never have married her if he had known that she would have so\r\n      many years before her, when he had so few. It was not natural.\r\n      She would live fifteen or twenty years after he was gone, and\r\n      might spend a lot of money; she had always had extravagant\r\n      tastes. For all he knew she might want to buy one of these\r\n      motor-cars. Cicely and Rachel and Imogen and all the young\r\n      people\xe2\x80\x94they all rode those bicycles now and went off Goodness\r\n      knew where. And now Roger was gone. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t know\xe2\x80\x94couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell!\r\n      The family was breaking up. Soames would know how much his uncle\r\n      had left. Curiously he thought of Roger as Soames\xe2\x80\x99 uncle not as\r\n      his own brother. Soames! It was more and more the one solid spot\r\n      in a vanishing world. Then Emily\xe2\x80\x99s real voice\r\n      said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHave you had a nice nap, James?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Nap! What did\r\n      he take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Agitated within by Winifred\xe2\x80\x99s news, and goaded by the constant\r\n      reiteration of this jeremiad, Emily said calmly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe took Winifred\xe2\x80\x99s pearls and a dancer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said James, and sat down.\r\n\r\n      His sudden collapse alarmed her, and smoothing his forehead, she\r\n      said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNow, don\xe2\x80\x99t fuss, James!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      A dusky red had spread over James\xe2\x80\x99 cheeks and forehead.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI paid for them,\xe2\x80\x9d he said tremblingly; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a thief! I\xe2\x80\x94I knew\r\n      how it would be. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be the death of me; he ....\xe2\x80\x9d Words failed\r\n      him and he sat quite still. She could not see the tenacious Forsyte spirit\r\n      working in that thin, tremulous shape against the extravagance of\r\n      the emotion called up by this outrage on Forsyte principles\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n      Forsyte spirit deep in there, saying: \xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t get into a\r\n      fantod, it\xe2\x80\x99ll never do. Where\xe2\x80\x99s Soames?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll be in directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo, he won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said James, almost fiercely; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s at the\r\n      funeral. A little\r\n      sigh of relief escaped his lips, and putting the glass down, he\r\n      said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThere you are! Dartie\xe2\x80\x99s gone to Buenos Aires.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames nodded. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cgood riddance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      A wave of assuagement passed over James\xe2\x80\x99 brain. Soames knew.\r\n      Soames was the only one of them all who had sense. Why couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      he come and live at home? He had no son of his own. And he said\r\n      plaintively:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAt my age I get nervous. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been to see Winifred. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to take steps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      And he thought: \xe2\x80\x9cYes, and you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t hear of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      James looked up; his long white whiskers quivered, his thin\r\n      throat between the points of his collar looked very gristly and\r\n      naked.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been very poorly all day,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthey never tell me\r\n      anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames\xe2\x80\x99 heart twitched.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s all right. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to worry about. Will you\r\n      come up now?\xe2\x80\x9d and he put his hand under his father\xe2\x80\x99s arm.\r\n\r\n      James obediently and tremulously raised himself, and together\r\n      they went slowly across the room, which had a rich look in the\r\n      firelight, and out to the stairs. Very slowly they ascended.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, my boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said James at his bedroom door.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Soames. His hand stroked down the\r\n      sleeve beneath the shawl; it seemed to have almost nothing in it,\r\n      so thin was the arm. And, turning away from the light in the\r\n      opening doorway, he went up the extra flight to his own bedroom.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI want a son,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, sitting on the edge of his bed; \xe2\x80\x9c_I\r\n      want a son_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER VI NO-LONGER-YOUNG JOLYON AT HOME\r\n\r\n\r\n      Trees take little account of time, and the old oak on the upper\r\n      lawn at Robin Hill looked no day older than when Bosinney\r\n      sprawled under it and said to Soames: \xe2\x80\x9cForsyte, I\xe2\x80\x99ve found the\r\n      very place for your house.\xe2\x80\x9d Since then Swithin had dreamed, and\r\n      old Jolyon died, beneath its branches. And now, close to the\r\n      swing, no-longer-young Jolyon often painted there. Of all spots\r\n      in the world it was perhaps the most sacred to him, for he had\r\n      loved his father.\r\n\r\n      Contemplating its great girth\xe2\x80\x94crinkled and a little mossed, but\r\n      not yet hollow\xe2\x80\x94he would speculate on the passage of time. That\r\n      tree had seen, perhaps, all real English history; it dated, he\r\n      shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder, from the days of Elizabeth at least. His own\r\n      fifty years were as nothing to its wood. When the house behind\r\n      it, which he now owned, was three hundred years of age instead of\r\n      twelve, that tree might still be standing there, vast and\r\n      hollow\xe2\x80\x94for who would commit such sacrilege as to cut it down? A\r\n      Forsyte might perhaps still be living in that house, to guard it\r\n      jealously. And Jolyon would wonder what the house would look like\r\n      coated with such age. Wistaria was already about its walls\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n      new look had gone. Would it hold its own and keep the dignity\r\n      Bosinney had bestowed on it, or would the giant London have\r\n      lapped it round and made it into an asylum in the midst of a\r\n      jerry-built wilderness? Often, within and without of it, he was\r\n      persuaded that Bosinney had been moved by the spirit when he\r\n      built. He had put his heart into that house, indeed! It might\r\n      even become one of the \xe2\x80\x9chomes of England\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a rare achievement for\r\n      a house in these degenerate days of building. And the aesthetic\r\n      spirit, moving hand in hand with his Forsyte sense of possessive\r\n      continuity, dwelt with pride and pleasure on his ownership\r\n      thereof. There was the smack of reverence and ancestor-worship\r\n      (if only for one ancestor) in his desire to hand this house down\r\n      to his son and his son\xe2\x80\x99s son. His father had loved the house, had\r\n      loved the view, the grounds, that tree; his last years had been\r\n      happy there, and no one had lived there before him. These last\r\n      eleven years at Robin Hill had formed in Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s life as a\r\n      painter, the important period of success. He was now in the very\r\n      van of water-colour art, hanging on the line everywhere. His\r\n      drawings fetched high prices. Specialising in that one medium\r\n      with the tenacity of his breed, he had \xe2\x80\x9carrived\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94rather late, but\r\n      not too late for a member of the family which made a point of\r\n      living for ever. His art had really deepened and improved. In\r\n      conformity with his position he had grown a short fair beard,\r\n      which was just beginning to grizzle, and hid his Forsyte chin;\r\n      his brown face had lost the warped expression of his ostracised\r\n      period\xe2\x80\x94he looked, if anything, younger. The loss of his wife in\r\n      1894 had been one of those domestic tragedies which turn out in\r\n      the end for the good of all. He had, indeed, loved her to the\r\n      last, for his was an affectionate spirit, but she had become\r\n      increasingly difficult: jealous of her step-daughter June,\r\n      jealous even of her own little daughter Holly, and making\r\n      ceaseless plaint that he could not love her, ill as she was, and\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cuseless to everyone, and better dead.\xe2\x80\x9d He had mourned her\r\n      sincerely, but his face had looked younger since she died. If she\r\n      could only have believed that she made him happy, how much\r\n      happier would the twenty years of their companionship have been!\r\n\r\n      June had never really got on well with her who had reprehensibly\r\n      taken her own mother\xe2\x80\x99s place; and ever since old Jolyon died she\r\n      had been established in a sort of studio in London. But she had\r\n      come back to Robin Hill on her stepmother\xe2\x80\x99s death, and gathered\r\n      the reins there into her small decided hands. Jolly was then at\r\n      Harrow; Holly still learning from Mademoiselle Beauce. There had\r\n      been nothing to keep Jolyon at home, and he had removed his grief\r\n      and his paint-box abroad. There he had wandered, for the most\r\n      part in Brittany, and at last had fetched up in Paris. He had\r\n      stayed there several months, and come back with the younger face\r\n      and the short fair beard. Essentially a man who merely lodged in\r\n      any house, it had suited him perfectly that June should reign at\r\n      Robin Hill, so that he was free to go off with his easel where\r\n      and when he liked. She was inclined, it is true, to regard the\r\n      house rather as an asylum for her _prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9s;_ but his own outcast\r\n      days had filled Jolyon for ever with sympathy towards an outcast,\r\n      and June\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9clame ducks\xe2\x80\x9d about the place did not annoy him. By all\r\n      means let her have them down\xe2\x80\x94and feed them up; and though his\r\n      slightly cynical humour perceived that they ministered to his\r\n      daughter\xe2\x80\x99s love of domination as well as moved her warm heart, he\r\n      never ceased to admire her for having so many ducks. He fell,\r\n      indeed, year by year into a more and more detached and brotherly\r\n      attitude towards his own son and daughters, treating them with a\r\n      sort of whimsical equality. When he went down to Harrow to see\r\n      Jolly, he never quite knew which of them was the elder, and would\r\n      sit eating cherries with him out of one paper bag, with an\r\n      affectionate and ironical smile twisting up an eyebrow and\r\n      curling his lips a little. And he was always careful to have\r\n      money in his pocket, and to be modish in his dress, so that his\r\n      son need not blush for him. They were perfect friends, but never\r\n      seemed to have occasion for verbal confidences, both having the\r\n      competitive self-consciousness of Forsytes. They knew they would\r\n      stand by each other in scrapes, but there was no need to talk\r\n      about it. Jolyon had a striking horror\xe2\x80\x94partly original sin, but\r\n      partly the result of his early immorality\xe2\x80\x94of the moral attitude.\r\n      The most he could ever have said to his son would have been:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLook here, old man; don\xe2\x80\x99t forget you\xe2\x80\x99re a gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d and then\r\n      have wondered whimsically whether that was not a snobbish\r\n      sentiment. The great cricket match was perhaps the most searching\r\n      and awkward time they annually went through together, for Jolyon\r\n      had been at Eton. They would be particularly careful during that\r\n      match, continually saying: \xe2\x80\x9cHooray! Oh! hard luck, old man!\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHooray! And\r\n      Jolyon would wear a grey top hat, instead of his usual soft one,\r\n      to save his son\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, for a black top hat he could not\r\n      stomach. When Jolly went up to Oxford, Jolyon went up with him,\r\n      amused, humble, and a little anxious not to discredit his boy\r\n      amongst all these youths who seemed so much more assured and old\r\n      than himself. He often thought, \xe2\x80\x9cGlad I\xe2\x80\x99m a painter\xe2\x80\x9d for he had\r\n      long dropped under-writing at Lloyds\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s so innocuous. You\r\n      can\xe2\x80\x99t look down on a painter\xe2\x80\x94you can\xe2\x80\x99t take him seriously\r\n      enough.\xe2\x80\x9d For Jolly, who had a sort of natural lordliness, had\r\n      passed at once into a very small set, who secretly amused his\r\n      father. The boy had fair hair which curled a little, and his\r\n      grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s deepset iron-grey eyes. He was well-built and very\r\n      upright, and always pleased Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic sense, so that he\r\n      was a tiny bit afraid of him, as artists ever are of those of\r\n      their own sex whom they admire physically. On that occasion,\r\n      however, he actually did screw up his courage to give his son\r\n      advice, and this was it:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLook here, old man, you\xe2\x80\x99re bound to get into debt; mind you come\r\n      to me at once. Of course, I\xe2\x80\x99ll always pay them. But you might\r\n      remember that one respects oneself more afterwards if one pays\r\n      one\xe2\x80\x99s own way. And don\xe2\x80\x99t ever borrow, except from me, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And Jolly had said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right, Dad, I won\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d and he never had.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAnd there\xe2\x80\x99s just one other thing. He\r\n      under-estimated, no doubt, the change in the spirit of the age\r\n      since he himself went up to Cambridge in \xe2\x80\x9965; and perhaps he\r\n      underestimated, too, his boy\xe2\x80\x99s power of understanding that he was\r\n      tolerant to the very bone. It was that tolerance of his, and\r\n      possibly his scepticism, which ever made his relations towards\r\n      June so queerly defensive. She was such a decided mortal; knew\r\n      her own mind so terribly well; wanted things so inexorably until\r\n      she got them\xe2\x80\x94and then, indeed, often dropped them like a hot\r\n      potato. Her mother had been like that, whence had come all those\r\n      tears. Not that his incompatibility with his daughter was\r\n      anything like what it had been with the first Mrs. Young Jolyon.\r\n      One could be amused where a daughter was concerned; in a wife\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      case one could not be amused. To see June set her heart and jaw\r\n      on a thing until she got it was all right, because it was never\r\n      anything which interfered fundamentally with Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s liberty\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n      one thing on which his jaw was also absolutely rigid, a\r\n      considerable jaw, under that short grizzling beard. Nor was there\r\n      ever any necessity for real heart-to-heart encounters. One could\r\n      break away into irony\xe2\x80\x94as indeed he often had to. But the real\r\n      trouble with June was that she had never appealed to his\r\n      aesthetic sense, though she might well have, with her red-gold\r\n      hair and her viking-coloured eyes, and that touch of the\r\n      Berserker in her spirit. He watched this younger daughter of his through the\r\n      duckling stage with extraordinary interest. Would she come out a\r\n      swan? With her sallow oval face and her grey wistful eyes and\r\n      those long dark lashes, she might, or she might not. Only this\r\n      last year had he been able to guess. Yes, she would be a\r\n      swan\xe2\x80\x94rather a dark one, always a shy one, but an authentic swan.\r\n      She was eighteen now, and Mademoiselle Beauce was gone\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n      excellent lady had removed, after eleven years haunted by her\r\n      continuous reminiscences of the \xe2\x80\x9cwell-brrred little Tayleurs,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\n      another family whose bosom would now be agitated by her\r\n      reminiscences of the \xe2\x80\x9cwell-brrred little Forsytes.\xe2\x80\x9d She had\r\n      taught Holly to speak French like herself.\r\n\r\n      Portraiture was not Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s forte, but he had already drawn his\r\n      younger daughter three times, and was drawing her a fourth, on\r\n      the afternoon of October 4th, 1899, when a card was brought to\r\n      him which caused his eyebrows to go up:\r\n                     MR. SOAMES FORSYTE\r\n           THE SHELTER,         CONNOISSEURS CLUB, MAPLEDURHAM.        \r\n           ST. JAMES\xe2\x80\x99S.\r\n      But here the Forsyte Saga must digress again....\r\n\r\n      To return from a long travel in Spain to a darkened house, to a\r\n      little daughter bewildered with tears, to the sight of a loved\r\n      father lying peaceful in his last sleep, had never been, was\r\n      never likely to be, forgotten by so impressionable and\r\n      warm-hearted a man as Jolyon. A sense as of mystery, too, clung\r\n      to that sad day, and about the end of one whose life had been so\r\n      well-ordered, balanced, and above-board. It seemed incredible\r\n      that his father could thus have vanished without, as it were,\r\n      announcing his intention, without last words to his son, and due\r\n      farewells. And those incoherent allusions of little Holly to \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\n      lady in grey,\xe2\x80\x9d of Mademoiselle Beauce to a Madame Errant (as it\r\n      sounded) involved all things in a mist, lifted a little when he\r\n      read his father\xe2\x80\x99s will and the codicil thereto. It had been his\r\n      duty as executor of that will and codicil to inform Irene, wife\r\n      of his cousin Soames, of her life interest in fifteen thousand\r\n      pounds. He had called on her to explain that the existing\r\n      investment in India Stock, ear-marked to meet the charge, would\r\n      produce for her the interesting net sum of \xc2\xa3430 odd a year, clear\r\n      of income tax. This was but the third time he had seen his cousin\r\n      Soames\xe2\x80\x99 wife\xe2\x80\x94if indeed she was still his wife, of which he was\r\n      not quite sure. He remembered having seen her sitting in the\r\n      Botanical Gardens waiting for Bosinney\xe2\x80\x94a passive, fascinating\r\n      figure, reminding him of Titian\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHeavenly Love,\xe2\x80\x9d and again,\r\n      when, charged by his father, he had gone to Montpellier Square on\r\n      the afternoon when Bosinney\xe2\x80\x99s death was known. He still recalled\r\n      vividly her sudden appearance in the drawing-room doorway on that\r\n      occasion\xe2\x80\x94her beautiful face, passing from wild eagerness of hope\r\n      to stony despair; remembered the compassion he had felt, Soames\xe2\x80\x99\r\n      snarling smile, his words, \xe2\x80\x9cWe are not at home!\xe2\x80\x9d and the slam of\r\n      the front door.\r\n\r\n      This third time he saw a face and form more beautiful\xe2\x80\x94freed from\r\n      that warp of wild hope and despair. Looking at her, he thought:\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are just what the Dad would have admired!\xe2\x80\x9d And the\r\n      strange story of his father\xe2\x80\x99s Indian summer became slowly clear\r\n      to him. She spoke of old Jolyon with reverence and tears in her\r\n      eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was so wonderfully kind to me; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why. He\r\n      looked so beautiful and peaceful sitting in that chair under the\r\n      tree; it was I who first came on him sitting there, you know.\r\n      Such a lovely day. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think an end could have been happier.\r\n      We should all like to go out like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cQuite right!\xe2\x80\x9d he had thought. \xe2\x80\x9cWe should all like to go out in\r\n      full summer with beauty stepping towards us across a lawn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And looking round the little, almost empty drawing-room, he had\r\n      asked her what she was going to do now. \xe2\x80\x9cI am going to live again\r\n      a little, Cousin Jolyon. It\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful to have money of one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      own. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never had any. I shall keep this flat, I think; I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\n      used to it; but I shall be able to go to Italy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cExactly!\xe2\x80\x9d Jolyon had murmured, looking at her faintly smiling\r\n      lips; and he had gone away thinking: \xe2\x80\x9cA fascinating woman! What a\r\n      waste! I\xe2\x80\x99m glad the Dad left her that money.\xe2\x80\x9d He had not seen her\r\n      again, but every quarter he had signed her cheque, forwarding it\r\n      to her bank, with a note to the Chelsea flat to say that he had\r\n      done so; and always he had received a note in acknowledgment,\r\n      generally from the flat, but sometimes from Italy; so that her\r\n      personality had become embodied in slightly scented grey paper,\r\n      an upright fine handwriting, and the words, \xe2\x80\x9cDear Cousin Jolyon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      Man of property that he now was, the slender cheque he signed\r\n      often gave rise to the thought: \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I suppose she just\r\n      manages\xe2\x80\x9d; sliding into a vague wonder how she was faring\r\n      otherwise in a world of men not wont to let beauty go\r\n      unpossessed. At first Holly had spoken of her sometimes, but\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cladies in grey\xe2\x80\x9d soon fade from children\xe2\x80\x99s memories; and the\r\n      tightening of June\xe2\x80\x99s lips in those first weeks after her\r\n      grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s death whenever her former friend\xe2\x80\x99s name was\r\n      mentioned, had discouraged allusion. I\xe2\x80\x99m frightfully glad she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      independent now....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      On receiving Soames\xe2\x80\x99 card, Jolyon said to the maid\xe2\x80\x94for he could\r\n      not abide butlers\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cShow him into the study, please, and say I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\n      be there in a minute\xe2\x80\x9d; and then he looked at Holly and asked:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember \xe2\x80\x98the lady in grey,\xe2\x80\x99 who used to give you\r\n      music-lessons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, why? He\xe2\x80\x99s pathetic!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER VII THE COLT AND THE FILLY\r\n\r\n\r\n      When young Val left the presence of the last generation he was\r\n      thinking: \xe2\x80\x9cThis is jolly dull! June says so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cCruel?\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Val. \xe2\x80\x9cOh! that\xe2\x80\x99s all rot. Who\xe2\x80\x99s June?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMy sister\xe2\x80\x94my half-sister, you know\xe2\x80\x94much older than me.\xe2\x80\x9d She had\r\n      put her hands up to both cheeks of Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s horse, and was rubbing\r\n      her nose against its nose with a gentle snuffling noise which\r\n      seemed to have an hypnotic effect on the animal. Val contemplated\r\n      her cheek resting against the horse\xe2\x80\x99s nose, and her eyes gleaming\r\n      round at him. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s really a duck,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n\r\n      They returned to the house less talkative, followed this time by\r\n      the dog Balthasar, walking more slowly than anything on earth,\r\n      and clearly expecting them not to exceed his speed limit.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a ripping place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val from under the oak tree,\r\n      where they had paused to allow the dog Balthasar to come up.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Holly, and sighed. \xe2\x80\x9cOf course I want to go\r\n      everywhere. I wish I were a gipsy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, gipsies are jolly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Val, with a conviction which\r\n      had just come to him; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re rather like one, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly\xe2\x80\x99s face shone suddenly and deeply, like dark leaves gilded\r\n      by the sun.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTo go mad-rabbiting everywhere and see everything, and live in\r\n      the open\xe2\x80\x94oh! wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it be fun?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s do it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Val.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, let\xe2\x80\x99s!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99d be grand sport, just you and I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Then Holly perceived the quaintness and gushed.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, we\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val obstinately, but reddening\r\n      too.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI believe in doing things you want to do. What\xe2\x80\x99s down there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThe kitchen-garden, and the pond and the coppice, and the farm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s go down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly glanced back at the house.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s tea-time, I expect; there\xe2\x80\x99s Dad beckoning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val, uttering a growly sound, followed her towards the house.\r\n\r\n      When they re-entered the hall gallery the sight of two\r\n      middle-aged Forsytes drinking tea together had its magical\r\n      effect, and they became quite silent. It was, indeed, an\r\n      impressive spectacle. The two were seated side by side on an\r\n      arrangement in marqueterie which looked like three silvery pink\r\n      chairs made one, with a low tea-table in front of them. They\r\n      seemed to have taken up that position, as far apart as the seat\r\n      would permit, so that they need not look at each other too much;\r\n      and they were eating and drinking rather than talking\xe2\x80\x94Soames with\r\n      his air of despising the tea-cake as it disappeared, Jolyon of\r\n      finding himself slightly amusing. To the casual eye neither would\r\n      have seemed greedy, but both were getting through a good deal of\r\n      sustenance. The two young ones having been supplied with food,\r\n      the process went on silent and absorbative, till, with the advent\r\n      of cigarettes, Jolyon said to Soames:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAnd how\xe2\x80\x99s Uncle James?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThanks, very shaky.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re a wonderful family, aren\xe2\x80\x99t we? The other day I was\r\n      calculating the average age of the ten old Forsytes from my\r\n      father\xe2\x80\x99s family Bible. I make it eighty-four already, and five\r\n      still living. They ought to beat the record;\xe2\x80\x9d and looking\r\n      whimsically at Soames, he added:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe aren\xe2\x80\x99t the men they were, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you really think I shall admit that I\xe2\x80\x99m not\r\n      their equal\xe2\x80\x9d. he seemed to be saying, \xe2\x80\x9cor that I\xe2\x80\x99ve got to give\r\n      up anything, especially life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe may live to their age, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\n      self-consciousness is a handicap, you know, and that\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\n      difference between us. We\xe2\x80\x99ve lost conviction. How and when\r\n      self-consciousness was born I never can make out. My father had a\r\n      little, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe any other of the old Forsytes ever\r\n      had a scrap. Never to see yourself as others see you, it\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\n      wonderful preservative. The whole history of the last century is\r\n      in the difference between us. And between us and you,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\n      gazing through a ring of smoke at Val and Holly, uncomfortable\r\n      under his quizzical regard, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99ll be\xe2\x80\x94another difference. I\r\n      wonder what.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames took out his watch.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe must go,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif we\xe2\x80\x99re to catch our train.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cUncle Soames never misses a train,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Val, with his mouth\r\n      full.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I?\xe2\x80\x9d Soames answered simply.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d grumbled Val, \xe2\x80\x9cother people do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At the front door he gave Holly\xe2\x80\x99s slim brown hand a long and\r\n      surreptitious squeeze.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLook out for me to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he whispered; \xe2\x80\x9cthree o\xe2\x80\x99clock. I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\n      wait for you in the road; it\xe2\x80\x99ll save time. We\xe2\x80\x99ll have a ripping\r\n      ride.\xe2\x80\x9d He gazed back at her from the lodge gate, and, but for the\r\n      principles of a man about town, would have waved his hand. He\r\n      felt in no mood to tolerate his uncle\xe2\x80\x99s conversation. But he was\r\n      not in danger. Soames preserved a perfect muteness, busy with\r\n      far-away thoughts.\r\n\r\n      The yellow leaves came down about those two walking the mile and\r\n      a half which Soames had traversed so often in those long-ago days\r\n      when he came down to watch with secret pride the building of the\r\n      house\xe2\x80\x94that house which was to have been the home of him and her\r\n      from whom he was now going to seek release. He looked back once,\r\n      up that endless vista of autumn lane between the yellowing\r\n      hedges. What an age ago! \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to see her,\xe2\x80\x9d he had said\r\n      to Jolyon. Was that true? \xe2\x80\x9cI may have to,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; and he\r\n      shivered, seized by one of those queer shudderings that they say\r\n      mean footsteps on one\xe2\x80\x99s grave. A chilly world! A queer world! And\r\n      glancing sidelong at his nephew, he thought: \xe2\x80\x9cWish I were his\r\n      age! I wonder what she\xe2\x80\x99s like now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER VIII JOLYON PROSECUTES TRUSTEESHIP\r\n\r\n\r\n      When those two were gone Jolyon did not return to his painting,\r\n      for daylight was failing, but went to the study, craving\r\n      unconsciously a revival of that momentary vision of his father\r\n      sitting in the old leather chair with his knees crossed and his\r\n      straight eyes gazing up from under the dome of his massive brow.\r\n      Often in this little room, cosiest in the house, Jolyon would\r\n      catch a moment of communion with his father. Not, indeed, that he\r\n      had definitely any faith in the persistence of the human\r\n      spirit\xe2\x80\x94the feeling was not so logical\xe2\x80\x94it was, rather, an\r\n      atmospheric impact, like a scent, or one of those strong\r\n      animistic impressions from forms, or effects of light, to which\r\n      those with the artist\xe2\x80\x99s eye are especially prone. Here only\xe2\x80\x94in\r\n      this little unchanged room where his father had spent the most of\r\n      his waking hours\xe2\x80\x94could be retrieved the feeling that he was not\r\n      quite gone, that the steady counsel of that old spirit and the\r\n      warmth of his masterful lovability endured.\r\n\r\n      What would his father be advising now, in this sudden\r\n      recrudescence of an old tragedy\xe2\x80\x94what would he say to this menace\r\n      against her to whom he had taken such a fancy in the last weeks\r\n      of his life? \xe2\x80\x9cI must do my best for her,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9che\r\n      left her to me in his will. But what _is_ the best?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And as if seeking to regain the sapience, the balance and shrewd\r\n      common sense of that old Forsyte, he sat down in the ancient\r\n      chair and crossed his knees. But he felt a mere shadow sitting\r\n      there; nor did any inspiration come, while the fingers of the\r\n      wind tapped on the darkening panes of the french-window.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGo and see her?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cor ask her to come down here?\r\n      What\xe2\x80\x99s her life been? What is it now, I wonder? Beastly to rake\r\n      up things at this time of day.\xe2\x80\x9d Again the figure of his cousin\r\n      standing with a hand on a front door of a fine olive-green leaped\r\n      out, vivid, like one of those figures from old-fashioned clocks\r\n      when the hour strikes; and his words sounded in Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s ears\r\n      clearer than any chime: \xe2\x80\x9cI manage my own affairs. I\xe2\x80\x99ve told you\r\n      once, I tell you again: We are not at home.\xe2\x80\x9d The repugnance he\r\n      had then felt for Soames\xe2\x80\x94for his flat-cheeked, shaven face full\r\n      of spiritual bull-doggedness; for his spare, square, sleek figure\r\n      slightly crouched as it were over the bone he could not\r\n      digest\xe2\x80\x94came now again, fresh as ever, nay, with an odd increase.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI dislike him,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cI dislike him to the very roots of\r\n      me. And that\xe2\x80\x99s lucky; it\xe2\x80\x99ll make it easier for me to back his\r\n      wife.\xe2\x80\x9d Half-artist, and half-Forsyte, Jolyon was constitutionally\r\n      averse from what he termed \xe2\x80\x9cructions\xe2\x80\x9d; unless angered, he\r\n      conformed deeply to that classic description of the she-dog,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cEr\xe2\x80\x99d ruther run than fight.\xe2\x80\x9d A little smile became settled in\r\n      his beard. Ironical that Soames should come down here\xe2\x80\x94to this\r\n      house, built for himself! How he had gazed and gaped at this ruin\r\n      of his past intention; furtively nosing at the walls and\r\n      stairway, appraising everything! And intuitively Jolyon thought:\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI believe the fellow even now would like to be living here. He\r\n      could never leave off longing for what he once owned! Well, I\r\n      must act, somehow or other; but it\xe2\x80\x99s a bore\xe2\x80\x94a great bore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Late that evening he wrote to the Chelsea flat, asking if Irene\r\n      would see him.\r\n\r\n      The old century which had seen the plant of individualism flower\r\n      so wonderfully was setting in a sky orange with coming storms.\r\n      Rumours of war added to the briskness of a London turbulent at\r\n      the close of the summer holidays. And the streets to Jolyon, who\r\n      was not often up in town, had a feverish look, due to these new\r\n      motorcars and cabs, of which he disapproved aesthetically. He\r\n      counted these vehicles from his hansom, and made the proportion\r\n      of them one in twenty. \xe2\x80\x9cThey were one in thirty about a year\r\n      ago,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99ve come to stay. Just so much more\r\n      rattling round of wheels and general stink\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94for he was one of\r\n      those rather rare Liberals who object to anything new when it\r\n      takes a material form; and he instructed his driver to get down\r\n      to the river quickly, out of the traffic, desiring to look at the\r\n      water through the mellowing screen of plane-trees. At the little\r\n      block of flats which stood back some fifty yards from the\r\n      Embankment, he told the cabman to wait, and went up to the first\r\n      floor.\r\n\r\n      Yes, Mrs. Heron was at home!\r\n\r\n      The effect of a settled if very modest income was at once\r\n      apparent to him remembering the threadbare refinement in that\r\n      tiny flat eight years ago when he announced her good fortune.\r\n      Everything was now fresh, dainty, and smelled of flowers. The\r\n      general effect was silvery with touches of black, hydrangea\r\n      colour, and gold. \xe2\x80\x9cA woman of great taste,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. Time had\r\n      dealt gently with Jolyon, for he was a Forsyte. But with Irene\r\n      Time hardly seemed to deal at all, or such was his impression.\r\n      She appeared to him not a day older, standing there in\r\n      mole-coloured velvet corduroy, with soft dark eyes and dark gold\r\n      hair, with outstretched hand and a little smile.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you sit down?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He had probably never occupied a chair with a fuller sense of\r\n      embarrassment.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou look absolutely unchanged,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you look younger, Cousin Jolyon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon ran his hands through his hair, whose thickness was still\r\n      a comfort to him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m ancient, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t feel it. That\xe2\x80\x99s one thing about\r\n      painting, it keeps you young. Titian lived to ninety-nine, and\r\n      had to have plague to kill him off. Do you know, the first time I\r\n      ever saw you I thought of a picture by him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhen did you see me for the first time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Botanical Gardens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHow did you know me, if you\xe2\x80\x99d never seen me before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBy someone who came up to you.\xe2\x80\x9d He was looking at her hardily,\r\n      but her face did not change; and she said quietly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes; many lives ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is _your_ recipe for youth, Irene?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cPeople who don\xe2\x80\x99t _live_ are wonderfully preserved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      H\xe2\x80\x99m! a bitter little saying! People who don\xe2\x80\x99t live! But an\r\n      opening, and he took it. \xe2\x80\x9cYou remember my Cousin Soames?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He saw her smile faintly at that whimsicality, and at once went\r\n      on:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe came to see me the day before yesterday! He wants a divorce.\r\n      Do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d The word seemed startled out of her. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter twelve years?\r\n      It\xe2\x80\x99s rather late. Won\xe2\x80\x99t it be difficult?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon looked hard into her face. \xe2\x80\x9cUnless....\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cUnless I have a lover now. But I have never had one since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      What did he feel at the simplicity and candour of those words?\r\n      Relief, surprise, pity! Venus for twelve years without a lover!\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you would give a good deal to be\r\n      free, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know. What does it matter, now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBut if you were to love again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI should love.\xe2\x80\x9d In that simple answer she seemed to sum up the\r\n      whole philosophy of one on whom the world had turned its back.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell! Is there anything you would like me to say to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOnly that I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry he\xe2\x80\x99s not free. He had his chance once. I\r\n      don\xe2\x80\x99t know why he didn\xe2\x80\x99t take it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBecause he was a Forsyte; we never part with things, you know,\r\n      unless we want something in their place; and not always then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Irene smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you, Cousin Jolyon?\xe2\x80\x94I think you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOf course, I\xe2\x80\x99m a bit of a mongrel\xe2\x80\x94not quite a pure Forsyte. I\r\n      never take the halfpennies off my cheques, I put them on,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\n      Jolyon uneasily.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what does Soames want in place of me now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know; perhaps children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      She was silent for a little, looking down.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s hard. I would help him to be free if I\r\n      could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon gazed into his hat, his embarrassment was increasing fast;\r\n      so was his admiration, his wonder, and his pity. She was so\r\n      lovely, and so lonely; and altogether it was such a coil!\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall have to see Soames. If there\xe2\x80\x99s anything\r\n      I can do for you I\xe2\x80\x99m always at your service. You must think of me\r\n      as a wretched substitute for my father. At all events I\xe2\x80\x99ll let\r\n      you know what happens when I speak to Soames. He may supply the\r\n      material himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      She shook her head.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou see, he has a lot to lose; and I have nothing. I should like\r\n      him to be free; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what I can do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNor I at the moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon, and soon after took his\r\n      leave. He went down to his hansom. Half-past three! Soames would\r\n      be at his office still.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTo the Poultry,\xe2\x80\x9d he called through the trap. In front of the\r\n      Houses of Parliament and in Whitehall, newsvendors were calling,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGrave situation in the Transvaal!\xe2\x80\x9d but the cries hardly roused\r\n      him, absorbed in recollection of that very beautiful figure, of\r\n      her soft dark glance, and the words: \xe2\x80\x9cI have never had one\r\n      since.\xe2\x80\x9d What on earth did such a woman do with her life,\r\n      back-watered like this? Solitary, unprotected, with every man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      hand against her or rather\xe2\x80\x94reaching out to grasp her at the least\r\n      sign. And year after year she went on like that!\r\n\r\n      The word \xe2\x80\x9cPoultry\xe2\x80\x9d above the passing citizens brought him back to\r\n      reality.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cForsyte, Bustard and Forsyte,\xe2\x80\x9d in black letters on a ground the\r\n      colour of peasoup, spurred him to a sort of vigour, and he went\r\n      up the stone stairs muttering: \xe2\x80\x9cFusty musty ownerships! Well, we\r\n      couldn\xe2\x80\x99t do without them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI want Mr. Soames Forsyte,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the boy who opened the\r\n      door.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Jolyon Forsyte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      The youth looked at him curiously, never having seen a Forsyte\r\n      with a beard, and vanished.\r\n\r\n      The offices of \xe2\x80\x9cForsyte, Bustard and Forsyte\xe2\x80\x9d had slowly absorbed\r\n      the offices of \xe2\x80\x9cTooting and Bowles,\xe2\x80\x9d and occupied the whole of\r\n      the first floor.\r\n\r\n      The firm consisted now of nothing but Soames and a number of\r\n      managing and articled clerks. The complete retirement of James\r\n      some six years ago had accelerated business, to which the final\r\n      touch of speed had been imparted when Bustard dropped off, worn\r\n      out, as many believed, by the suit of \xe2\x80\x9cFryer _versus_ Forsyte,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      more in Chancery than ever and less likely to benefit its\r\n      beneficiaries. Soames, with his saner grasp of actualities, had\r\n      never permitted it to worry him; on the contrary, he had long\r\n      perceived that Providence had presented him therein with \xc2\xa3200 a\r\n      year net in perpetuity, and\xe2\x80\x94why not?\r\n\r\n      When Jolyon entered, his cousin was drawing out a list of\r\n      holdings in Consols, which in view of the rumours of war he was\r\n      going to advise his companies to put on the market at once,\r\n      before other companies did the same. He looked round, sidelong,\r\n      and said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHow are you? Just one minute. Sit down, won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d And having\r\n      entered three amounts, and set a ruler to keep his place, he\r\n      turned towards Jolyon, biting the side of his flat forefinger....\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames frowned.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cShe has remained faithful to memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Having said that, Jolyon was ashamed. His cousin had flushed a\r\n      dusky yellowish red. What had made him tease the poor brute!\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI was to tell you she is sorry you are not free. Twelve years is\r\n      a long time. You know your law, and what chance it gives you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      Soames uttered a curious little grunt, and the two remained a\r\n      full minute without speaking. \xe2\x80\x9cLike wax!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon,\r\n      watching that close face, where the flush was fast subsiding.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll never give me a sign of what he\xe2\x80\x99s thinking, or going to\r\n      do. Like wax!\xe2\x80\x9d And he transferred his gaze to a plan of that\r\n      flourishing town, \xe2\x80\x9cBy-Street on Sea,\xe2\x80\x9d the future existence of\r\n      which lay exposed on the wall to the possessive instincts of the\r\n      firm\xe2\x80\x99s clients. The whimsical thought flashed through him: \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      wonder if I shall get a bill of costs for this\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98To attending Mr.\r\n      Jolyon Forsyte in the matter of my divorce, to receiving his\r\n      account of his visit to my wife, and to advising him to go and\r\n      see her again, sixteen and eightpence.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Suddenly Soames said: \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t go on like this. I tell you, I\r\n      can\xe2\x80\x99t go on like this.\xe2\x80\x9d His eyes were shifting from side to side,\r\n      like an animal\xe2\x80\x99s when it looks for way of escape. \xe2\x80\x9cHe really\r\n      suffers,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve no business to forget that, just\r\n      because I don\xe2\x80\x99t like him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d he said gently, \xe2\x80\x9cit lies with yourself. A man can\r\n      always put these things through if he\xe2\x80\x99ll take it on himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames turned square to him, with a sound which seemed to come\r\n      from somewhere very deep.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I suffer more than I\xe2\x80\x99ve suffered already? Why should\r\n      I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon could only shrug his shoulders. His reason agreed, his\r\n      instinct rebelled; he could not have said why.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour father,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Soames, \xe2\x80\x9ctook an interest in her\xe2\x80\x94why,\r\n      goodness knows! And I suppose you do too?\xe2\x80\x9d he gave Jolyon a sharp\r\n      look. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me that one only has to do another person a\r\n      wrong to get all the sympathy. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know in what way I was to\r\n      blame\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve never known. I always treated her well. I gave her\r\n      everything she could wish for. I wanted her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Again Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s reason nodded; again his instinct shook its head.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; \xe2\x80\x9cthere must be something wrong in me.\r\n      Yet if there is, I\xe2\x80\x99d rather be wrong than right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAfter all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames with a sort of glum fierceness, \xe2\x80\x9cshe was\r\n      my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      In a flash the thought went through his listener: \xe2\x80\x9cThere it is!\r\n      Ownerships! Well, we all own things. But\xe2\x80\x94human beings! Pah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou have to look at facts,\xe2\x80\x9d he said drily, \xe2\x80\x9cor rather the want\r\n      of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames gave him another quick suspicious look.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThe want of them?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, but I am not so sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve told you what she\r\n      said. It was explicit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMy experience has not been one to promote blind confidence in\r\n      her word. We shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon got up.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d he said curtly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Soames; and Jolyon went out trying to\r\n      understand the look, half-startled, half-menacing, on his\r\n      cousin\xe2\x80\x99s face. He sought Waterloo Station in a disturbed frame of\r\n      mind, as though the skin of his moral being had been scraped; and\r\n      all the way down in the train he thought of Irene in her lonely\r\n      flat, and of Soames in his lonely office, and of the strange\r\n      paralysis of life that lay on them both. \xe2\x80\x9cIn chancery!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\n      thought. \xe2\x80\x9cBoth their necks in chancery\xe2\x80\x94and her\xe2\x80\x99s so pretty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER IX VAL HEARS THE NEWS\r\n\r\n\r\n      The keeping of engagements had not as yet been a conspicuous\r\n      feature in the life of young Val Dartie, so that when he broke\r\n      two and kept one, it was the latter event which caused him, if\r\n      anything, the greater surprise, while jogging back to town from\r\n      Robin Hill after his ride with Holly. She had been even prettier\r\n      than he had thought her yesterday, on her silver-roan,\r\n      long-tailed \xe2\x80\x9cpalfrey\xe2\x80\x9d. and it seemed to him, self-critical in the\r\n      brumous October gloaming and the outskirts of London, that only\r\n      his boots had shone throughout their two-hour companionship. He\r\n      took out his new gold \xe2\x80\x9chunter\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94present from James\xe2\x80\x94and looked not\r\n      at the time, but at sections of his face in the glittering back\r\n      of its opened case. He had a temporary spot over one eyebrow, and\r\n      it displeased him, for it must have displeased her. Crum never\r\n      had any spots. Together with Crum rose the scene in the promenade\r\n      of the Pandemonium. To-day he had not had the faintest desire to\r\n      unbosom himself to Holly about his father. His father lacked\r\n      poetry, the stirrings of which he was feeling for the first time\r\n      in his nineteen years. The Liberty, with Cynthia Dark, that\r\n      almost mythical embodiment of rapture; the Pandemonium, with the\r\n      woman of uncertain age\xe2\x80\x94both seemed to Val completely \xe2\x80\x9coff,\xe2\x80\x9d fresh\r\n      from communion with this new, shy, dark-haired young cousin of\r\n      his. She rode \xe2\x80\x9cJolly well,\xe2\x80\x9d too, so that it had been all the more\r\n      flattering that she had let him lead her where he would in the\r\n      long gallops of Richmond Park, though she knew them so much\r\n      better than he did. He\r\n      should write to her, however, and she had promised to answer.\r\n      Perhaps, too, she would come up to Oxford to see her brother.\r\n      That thought was like the first star, which came out as he rode\r\n      into Padwick\xe2\x80\x99s livery stables in the purlieus of Sloane Square.\r\n      He got off and stretched himself luxuriously, for he had ridden\r\n      some twenty-five good miles. The Dartie within him made him\r\n      chaffer for five minutes with young Padwick concerning the\r\n      favourite for the Cambridgeshire; then with the words, \xe2\x80\x9cPut the\r\n      gee down to my account,\xe2\x80\x9d he walked away, a little wide at the\r\n      knees, and flipping his boots with his knotty little cane. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      don\xe2\x80\x99t feel a bit inclined to go out,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder if\r\n      mother will stand fizz for my last night!\xe2\x80\x9d With \xe2\x80\x9cfizz\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n      recollection, he could well pass a domestic evening.\r\n\r\n      When he came down, speckless after his bath, he found his mother\r\n      scrupulous in a low evening dress, and, to his annoyance, his\r\n      Uncle Soames. They stopped talking when he came in; then his\r\n      uncle said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99d better be told.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At those words, which meant something about his father, of\r\n      course, Val\xe2\x80\x99s first thought was of Holly. Was it anything\r\n      beastly? His mother began speaking.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour father,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in her fashionably appointed voice, while\r\n      her fingers plucked rather pitifully at sea-green brocade, \xe2\x80\x9cyour\r\n      father, my dear boy, has\xe2\x80\x94is not at Newmarket; he\xe2\x80\x99s on his way to\r\n      South America. He\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s left us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val looked from her to Soames. Left them! Was he sorry? Was he\r\n      fond of his father? It seemed to him that he did not know. One\xe2\x80\x99s father belonged to one,\r\n      could not go off in this fashion\xe2\x80\x94it was not done! Nor had he\r\n      always been the \xe2\x80\x9cbounder\xe2\x80\x9d of the Pandemonium promenade. There\r\n      were precious memories of tailors\xe2\x80\x99 shops and horses, tips at\r\n      school, and general lavish kindness, when in luck.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBut why?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. The mask of his mother\xe2\x80\x99s face was all disturbed; and\r\n      he burst out:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right, Mother, don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me! At Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s they gave you a\r\n      jolly good feed when they expected you, not otherwise. He decided\r\n      on Park Lane, not unmoved by the thought that to go up to Oxford\r\n      without affording his grandfather a chance to tip him was hardly\r\n      fair to either of them. His mother would hear he had been there,\r\n      of course, and might think it funny; but he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help that.\r\n      He rang the bell.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHullo, Warmson, any dinner for me, d\xe2\x80\x99you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re just going in, Master Val. Mr. Forsyte will be very glad\r\n      to see you. He was saying at lunch that he never saw you\r\n      nowadays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val grinned.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, here I am. Kill the fatted calf, Warmson, let\xe2\x80\x99s have\r\n      fizz.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Warmson smiled faintly\xe2\x80\x94in his opinion Val was a young limb.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI will ask Mrs. Forsyte, Master Val.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d Val grumbled, taking off his overcoat, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not at\r\n      school any more, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Warmson, not without a sense of humour, opened the door beyond\r\n      the stag\xe2\x80\x99s-horn coat stand, with the words:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Valerus, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cConfound him!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Val, entering.\r\n\r\n      A warm embrace, a \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Val!\xe2\x80\x9d from Emily, and a rather quavery\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cSo there you are at last!\xe2\x80\x9d from James, restored his sense of\r\n      dignity.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy didn\xe2\x80\x99t you let us know? There\xe2\x80\x99s only saddle of mutton.\r\n      Champagne, Warmson,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emily. And they went in.\r\n\r\n      At the great dining-table, shortened to its utmost, under which\r\n      so many fashionable legs had rested, James sat at one end, Emily\r\n      at the other, Val half-way between them; and something of the\r\n      loneliness of his grandparents, now that all their four children\r\n      were flown, reached the boy\xe2\x80\x99s spirit. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope I shall kick the\r\n      bucket long before I\xe2\x80\x99m as old as grandfather,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor\r\n      old chap, he\xe2\x80\x99s as thin as a rail!\xe2\x80\x9d And lowering his voice while\r\n      his grandfather and Warmson were in discussion about sugar in the\r\n      soup, he said to Emily:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s pretty brutal at home, Granny. I suppose you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, dear boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cUncle Soames was there when I left. What are you talking about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAbout Val\xe2\x80\x99s college,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Emily. \xe2\x80\x9cYoung Pariser was there,\r\n      James; you remember\xe2\x80\x94he nearly broke the Bank at Monte Carlo\r\n      afterwards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      James muttered that he did not know\xe2\x80\x94Val must look after himself\r\n      up there, or he\xe2\x80\x99d get into bad ways. How much will it be,\r\n      Grandfather?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThree hundred and fifty; it\xe2\x80\x99s too much. I had next to nothing at\r\n      your age.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val sighed. He had hoped for four, and been afraid of three. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      don\xe2\x80\x99t know what your young cousin has,\xe2\x80\x9d said James; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s up\r\n      there. Your\r\n      father....\xe2\x80\x9d and he was silent.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cCousin Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s got an awfully jolly place. I went down there\r\n      with Uncle Soames\xe2\x80\x94ripping stables.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured James profoundly. \xe2\x80\x9cThat house\xe2\x80\x94I knew how it would\r\n      be!\xe2\x80\x9d And he lapsed into gloomy meditation over his fish-bones.\r\n      His son\xe2\x80\x99s tragedy, and the deep cleavage it had caused in the\r\n      Forsyte family, had still the power to draw him down into a\r\n      whirlpool of doubts and misgivings. He seems awfully\r\n      worked-up about something to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Emily laid her finger on her lips, but the word Irene had caught\r\n      James\xe2\x80\x99 ear.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, staying a piece of mutton close to his\r\n      lips. \xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s been seeing her? But later,\r\n      when the saddle of mutton had been succeeded by sweet, savoury,\r\n      and dessert, and Val had received a cheque for twenty pounds and\r\n      his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s kiss\xe2\x80\x94like no other kiss in the world, from lips\r\n      pushed out with a sort of fearful suddenness, as if yielding to\r\n      weakness\xe2\x80\x94he returned to the charge in the hall.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTell us about Uncle Soames, Granny. I\r\n      remember she was jolly good-looking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x94er....\xe2\x80\x9d said Emily, \xe2\x80\x9cbehaved very badly. Why couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      father be prevented without its being made public?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Emily sighed. She had always lived rather in an atmosphere of\r\n      divorce, owing to her fashionable proclivities\xe2\x80\x94so many of those\r\n      whose legs had been under her table having gained a certain\r\n      notoriety. When, however, it touched her own family, she liked it\r\n      no better than other people. But she was eminently practical, and\r\n      a woman of courage, who never pursued a shadow in preference to\r\n      its substance.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour mother,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cwill be happier if she\xe2\x80\x99s quite free,\r\n      Val.
