He had always been very amiable; what\r\n      did Soames think?\r\n\r\n      Knowing that Jolyon was Irene\xe2\x80\x99s trustee, all felt the delicacy of\r\n      this question, and looked at Soames with interest. A faint pink\r\n      had come up in his cheeks.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s going grey,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      Indeed! Had Soames seen him? Soames nodded, and the pink\r\n      vanished.\r\n\r\n      James said suddenly: \xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      It so exactly expressed the sentiment of everybody present that\r\n      there was something behind everything, that nobody responded. But\r\n      at this moment Aunt Hester returned.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTimothy,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cTimothy has bought a map,\r\n      and he\xe2\x80\x99s put in\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s put in three flags.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Timothy had...! A sigh went round the company.\r\n\r\n      If Timothy had indeed put in three flags already, well!\xe2\x80\x94it showed\r\n      what the nation could do when it was roused. The war was as good\r\n      as over.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER XIII JOLYON FINDS OUT WHERE HE IS\r\n\r\n\r\n      Jolyon stood at the window in Holly\xe2\x80\x99s old night nursery,\r\n      converted into a studio, not because it had a north light, but\r\n      for its view over the prospect away to the Grand Stand at Epsom.\r\n      He shifted to the side window which overlooked the stableyard,\r\n      and whistled down to the dog Balthasar who lay for ever under the\r\n      clock tower. The old dog looked up and wagged his tail. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor old\r\n      boy!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon, shifting back to the other window.\r\n\r\n      He had been restless all this week, since his attempt to\r\n      prosecute trusteeship, uneasy in his conscience which was ever\r\n      acute, disturbed in his sense of compassion which was easily\r\n      excited, and with a queer sensation as if his feeling for beauty\r\n      had received some definite embodiment. Autumn was getting hold of\r\n      the old oak-tree, its leaves were browning. Sunshine had been\r\n      plentiful and hot this summer. As with trees, so with men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      lives! \xe2\x80\x9c_I_ ought to live long,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m getting\r\n      mildewed for want of heat. If I can\xe2\x80\x99t work, I shall be off to\r\n      Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d But memory of Paris gave him no pleasure. Besides, how\r\n      could he go? He must stay and see what Soames was going to do.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m her trustee. I can\xe2\x80\x99t leave her unprotected,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. It\r\n      had been striking him as curious how very clearly he could still\r\n      see Irene in her little drawing-room which he had only twice\r\n      entered. Her beauty must have a sort of poignant harmony! No\r\n      literal portrait would ever do her justice; the essence of her\r\n      was\xe2\x80\x94ah I what?... The noise of hoofs called him back to the other\r\n      window. Holly was riding into the yard on her long-tailed\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cpalfrey.\xe2\x80\x9d She looked up and he waved to her. She had been rather\r\n      silent lately; getting old, he supposed, beginning to want her\r\n      future, as they all did\xe2\x80\x94youngsters!\r\n\r\n      Time was certainly the devil! And with the feeling that to waste\r\n      this swift-travelling commodity was unforgivable folly, he took\r\n      up his brush. But it was no use; he could not concentrate his\r\n      eye\xe2\x80\x94besides, the light was going. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go up to town,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\n      thought. In the hall a servant met him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cA lady to see you, sir; Mrs. Heron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Extraordinary coincidence! Passing into the picture-gallery, as\r\n      it was still called, he saw Irene standing over by the window.\r\n\r\n      She came towards him saying:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been trespassing; I came up through the coppice and garden.\r\n      I always used to come that way to see Uncle Jolyon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t trespass here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9chistory makes that\r\n      impossible. I was just thinking of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Irene smiled. And it was as if something shone through; not mere\r\n      spirituality\xe2\x80\x94serener, completer, more alluring.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHistory!\xe2\x80\x9d she answered; \xe2\x80\x9cI once told Uncle Jolyon that love was\r\n      for ever. Well, it isn\xe2\x80\x99t. Only aversion lasts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon stared at her. Had she got over Bosinney at last?\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9caversion\xe2\x80\x99s deeper than love or hate because it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      a natural product of the nerves, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t change them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI came to tell you that Soames has been to see me. He said a\r\n      thing that frightened me. He said: \xe2\x80\x98You are still my wife!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Jolyon. \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought not to live alone.\xe2\x80\x9d And he\r\n      continued to stare at her, afflicted by the thought that where\r\n      Beauty was, nothing ever ran quite straight, which, no doubt, was\r\n      why so many people looked on it as immoral.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat more?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe asked me to shake hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDid you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes. When he came in I\xe2\x80\x99m sure he didn\xe2\x80\x99t want to; he changed\r\n      while he was there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAh! you certainly ought not to go on living there alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI know no woman I could ask; and I can\xe2\x80\x99t take a lover to order,\r\n      Cousin Jolyon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHeaven forbid!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a damnable position! Will you\r\n      stay to dinner? No? Well, let me see you back to town; I wanted\r\n      to go up this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTruly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTruly. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be ready in five minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      On that walk to the station they talked of pictures and music,\r\n      contrasting the English and French characters and the difference\r\n      in their attitude to Art. But to Jolyon the colours in the hedges\r\n      of the long straight lane, the twittering of chaffinches who kept\r\n      pace with them, the perfume of weeds being already burned, the\r\n      turn of her neck, the fascination of those dark eyes bent on him\r\n      now and then, the lure of her whole figure, made a deeper\r\n      impression than the remarks they exchanged. Unconsciously he held\r\n      himself straighter, walked with a more elastic step.\r\n\r\n      In the train he put her through a sort of catechism as to what\r\n      she did with her days.\r\n\r\n      Made her dresses, shopped, visited a hospital, played her piano,\r\n      translated from the French.\r\n\r\n      She had regular work from a publisher, it seemed, which\r\n      supplemented her income a little. She seldom went out in the\r\n      evening. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been living alone so long, you see, that I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      mind it a bit. I believe I\xe2\x80\x99m naturally solitary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know many people?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cVery few.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At Waterloo they took a hansom, and he drove with her to the door\r\n      of her mansions. Squeezing her hand at parting, he said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, you could always come to us at Robin Hill; you must\r\n      let me know everything that happens. Good-bye, Irene.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered softly.\r\n\r\n      Jolyon climbed back into his cab, wondering why he had not asked\r\n      her to dine and go to the theatre with him. Solitary, starved,\r\n      hung-up life that she had! \xe2\x80\x9cHotch Potch Club,\xe2\x80\x9d he said through\r\n      the trap-door. As his hansom debouched on to the Embankment, a\r\n      man in top-hat and overcoat passed, walking quickly, so close to\r\n      the wall that he seemed to be scraping it.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBy Jove!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon; \xe2\x80\x9cSoames himself! What\xe2\x80\x99s _he_ up to\r\n      now?\xe2\x80\x9d And, stopping the cab round the corner, he got out and\r\n      retraced his steps to where he could see the entrance to the\r\n      mansions. Soames had halted in front of them, and was looking up\r\n      at the light in her windows. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he goes in,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cwhat shall I do? What have I the right to do?\xe2\x80\x9d What the fellow\r\n      had said was true. She was still his wife, absolutely without\r\n      protection from annoyance! \xe2\x80\x9cWell, if he goes in,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      follow.\xe2\x80\x9d And he began moving towards the mansions. Again Soames\r\n      advanced; he was in the very entrance now. But suddenly he\r\n      stopped, spun round on his heel, and came back towards the river.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat now?\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon. \xe2\x80\x9cIn a dozen steps he\xe2\x80\x99ll recognise\r\n      me.\xe2\x80\x9d And he turned tail. His cousin\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps kept pace with\r\n      his own. But he reached his cab, and got in before Soames had\r\n      turned the corner. \xe2\x80\x9cGo on!\xe2\x80\x9d he said through the trap. Soames\xe2\x80\x99\r\n      figure ranged up alongside.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHansom!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cEngaged? Hallo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Jolyon. \xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      The quick suspicion on his cousin\xe2\x80\x99s face, white in the lamplight,\r\n      decided him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI can give you a lift,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif you\xe2\x80\x99re going West.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Soames, and got in.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been seeing Irene,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon when the cab had started.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou went to see her yesterday yourself, I understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s my wife, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      The tone, the half-lifted sneering lip, roused sudden anger in\r\n      Jolyon; but he subdued it.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to know best,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut if you want a divorce\r\n      it\xe2\x80\x99s not very wise to go seeing her, is it? One can\xe2\x80\x99t run with\r\n      the hare and hunt with the hounds?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re very good to warn me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have not made\r\n      up my mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c_She_ has,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon, looking straight before him; \xe2\x80\x9cyou can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      take things up, you know, as they were twelve years ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThat remains to be seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLook here!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s in a damnable position, and I am\r\n      the only person with any legal say in her affairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cExcept myself,\xe2\x80\x9d retorted Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cwho am also in a damnable\r\n      position. Hers is what she made for herself; mine what she made\r\n      for me. I am not at all sure that in her own interests I shan\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      require her to return to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Jolyon; and a shiver went through his whole\r\n      body.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you may mean by \xe2\x80\x98what,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d answered Soames\r\n      coldly; \xe2\x80\x9cyour say in her affairs is confined to paying out her\r\n      income; please bear that in mind. In choosing not to disgrace her\r\n      by a divorce, I retained my rights, and, as I say, I am not at\r\n      all sure that I shan\xe2\x80\x99t require to exercise them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMy God!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Jolyon, and he uttered a short laugh.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, and there was a deadly quality in his voice.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve not forgotten the nickname your father gave me, \xe2\x80\x98The man of\r\n      property\xe2\x80\x99. I\xe2\x80\x99m not called names for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThis is fantastic,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Jolyon. Well, the fellow couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      force his wife to live with him. Those days were past, anyway!\r\n      And he looked around at Soames with the thought: \xe2\x80\x9cIs he real,\r\n      this man?\xe2\x80\x9d But Soames looked very real, sitting square yet almost\r\n      elegant with the clipped moustache on his pale face, and a tooth\r\n      showing where a lip was lifted in a fixed smile. There was a long\r\n      silence, while Jolyon thought: \xe2\x80\x9cInstead of helping her, I\xe2\x80\x99ve made\r\n      things worse.\xe2\x80\x9d Suddenly Soames said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt would be the best thing that could happen to her in many\r\n      ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At those words such a turmoil began taking place in Jolyon that\r\n      he could barely sit still in the cab. It was as if he were boxed\r\n      up with hundreds of thousands of his countrymen, boxed up with\r\n      that something in the national character which had always been to\r\n      him revolting, something which he knew to be extremely natural\r\n      and yet which seemed to him inexplicable\xe2\x80\x94their intense belief in\r\n      contracts and vested rights, their complacent sense of virtue in\r\n      the exaction of those rights. Here beside him in the cab was the\r\n      very embodiment, the corporeal sum as it were, of the possessive\r\n      instinct\xe2\x80\x94his own kinsman, too! It was uncanny and intolerable!\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBut there\xe2\x80\x99s something more in it than that!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought with a\r\n      sick feeling. \xe2\x80\x9cThe dog, they say, returns to his vomit! The sight\r\n      of her has reawakened something. Beauty! The devil\xe2\x80\x99s in it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAs I say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not made up my mind. I shall be\r\n      obliged if you will kindly leave her quite alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon bit his lips; he who had always hated rows almost welcomed\r\n      the thought of one now.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI can give you no such promise,\xe2\x80\x9d he said shortly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cthen we know where we are. I\xe2\x80\x99ll get\r\n      down here.\xe2\x80\x9d And stopping the cab he got out without word or sign\r\n      of farewell. Jolyon travelled on to his Club.\r\n\r\n      The first news of the war was being called in the streets, but he\r\n      paid no attention. What could he do to help her? If only his\r\n      father were alive! _He_ could have done so much! But why could he\r\n      not do all that his father could have done? Was he not old\r\n      enough?\xe2\x80\x94turned fifty and twice married, with grown-up daughters\r\n      and a son. \xe2\x80\x9cQueer,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cIf she were plain I shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\n      thinking twice about it. Beauty is the devil, when you\xe2\x80\x99re\r\n      sensitive to it!\xe2\x80\x9d And into the Club reading-room he went with a\r\n      disturbed heart. In that very room he and Bosinney had talked one\r\n      summer afternoon; he well remembered even now the disguised and\r\n      secret lecture he had given that young man in the interests of\r\n      June, the diagnosis of the Forsytes he had hazarded; and how he\r\n      had wondered what sort of woman it was he was warning him\r\n      against. And now! He was almost in want of a warning himself.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s deuced funny!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9creally deuced funny!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER XIV SOAMES DISCOVERS WHAT HE WANTS\r\n\r\n      It is so much easier to say, \xe2\x80\x9cThen we know where we are,\xe2\x80\x9d than to\r\n      mean anything particular by the words. And in saying them Soames\r\n      did but vent the jealous rankling of his instincts. He got out of\r\n      the cab in a state of wary anger\xe2\x80\x94with himself for not having seen\r\n      Irene, with Jolyon for having seen her; and now with his\r\n      inability to tell exactly what he wanted.\r\n\r\n      He had abandoned the cab because he could not bear to remain\r\n      seated beside his cousin, and walking briskly eastwards he\r\n      thought: \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t trust that fellow Jolyon a yard. Once\r\n      outcast, always outcast!\xe2\x80\x9d The chap had a natural sympathy\r\n      with\xe2\x80\x94with\xe2\x80\x94laxity (he had shied at the word sin, because it was\r\n      too melodramatic for use by a Forsyte).\r\n\r\n      Indecision in desire was to him a new feeling. He was like a\r\n      child between a promised toy and an old one which had been taken\r\n      away from him; and he was astonished at himself. Only last Sunday\r\n      desire had seemed simple\xe2\x80\x94just his freedom and Annette. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go\r\n      and dine there,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. To see her might bring back his\r\n      singleness of intention, calm his exasperation, clear his mind.\r\n\r\n      The restaurant was fairly full\xe2\x80\x94a good many foreigners and folk\r\n      whom, from their appearance, he took to be literary or artistic.\r\n      Scraps of conversation came his way through the clatter of plates\r\n      and glasses. He distinctly heard the Boers sympathised with, the\r\n      British Government blamed. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t think much of their client\xc3\xa8le,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      he thought. He went stolidly through his dinner and special\r\n      coffee without making his presence known, and when at last he had\r\n      finished, was careful not to be seen going towards the sanctum of\r\n      Madame Lamotte. They were, as he entered, having supper\xe2\x80\x94such a\r\n      much nicer-looking supper than the dinner he had eaten that he\r\n      felt a kind of grief\xe2\x80\x94and they greeted him with a surprise so\r\n      seemingly genuine that he thought with sudden suspicion: \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      believe they knew I was here all the time.\xe2\x80\x9d He gave Annette a\r\n      look furtive and searching. So pretty, seemingly so candid; could\r\n      she be angling for him? He turned to Madame Lamotte and said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been dining here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Really! If she had only known! There were dishes she could have\r\n      recommended; what a pity! Soames was confirmed in his suspicion.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI must look out what I\xe2\x80\x99m doing!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought sharply.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAnother little cup of very special coffee, _monsieur;_ a\r\n      liqueur, Grand Marnier?\xe2\x80\x9d and Madame Lamotte rose to order these\r\n      delicacies.\r\n\r\n      Alone with Annette Soames said, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Annette?\xe2\x80\x9d with a defensive\r\n      little smile about his lips.\r\n\r\n      The girl blushed. This, which last Sunday would have set his\r\n      nerves tingling, now gave him much the same feeling a man has\r\n      when a dog that he owns wriggles and looks at him. He had a\r\n      curious sense of power, as if he could have said to her, \xe2\x80\x9cCome\r\n      and kiss me,\xe2\x80\x9d and she would have come. And yet\xe2\x80\x94it was strange\xe2\x80\x94but\r\n      there seemed another face and form in the room too; and the itch\r\n      in his nerves, was it for that\xe2\x80\x94or for this? He jerked his head\r\n      towards the restaurant and said: \xe2\x80\x9cYou have some queer customers.\r\n      Do you like this life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette looked up at him for a moment, looked down, and played\r\n      with her fork.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI do not like it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got her,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cif I want her. But do I want\r\n      her?\xe2\x80\x9d She was graceful, she was pretty\xe2\x80\x94very pretty; she was\r\n      fresh, she had taste of a kind. His eyes travelled round the\r\n      little room; but the eyes of his mind went another journey\xe2\x80\x94a\r\n      half-light, and silvery walls, a satinwood piano, a woman\r\n      standing against it, reined back as it were from him\xe2\x80\x94a woman with\r\n      white shoulders that he knew, and dark eyes that he had sought to\r\n      know, and hair like dull dark amber. And as in an artist who\r\n      strives for the unrealisable and is ever thirsty, so there rose\r\n      in him at that moment the thirst of the old passion he had never\r\n      satisfied.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d he said calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re young. There\xe2\x80\x99s everything before\r\n      _you_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette shook her head.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI think sometimes there is nothing before me but hard work. I am\r\n      not so in love with work as mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour mother is a wonder,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames, faintly mocking; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\r\n      will never let failure lodge in her house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette sighed. \xe2\x80\x9cIt must be wonderful to be rich.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! You\xe2\x80\x99ll be rich some day,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Soames, still with that\r\n      faint mockery; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Annette shrugged her shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9c_Monsieur_ is very kind.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\n      between her pouting lips she put a chocolate.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Soames, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re very pretty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Madame Lamotte, with coffee and liqueur, put an end to that\r\n      colloquy. Soames did not stay long.\r\n\r\n      Outside in the streets of Soho, which always gave him such a\r\n      feeling of property improperly owned, he mused. If only Irene had\r\n      given him a son, he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t now be squirming after women! The\r\n      thought had jumped out of its little dark sentry-box in his inner\r\n      consciousness. A son\xe2\x80\x94something to look forward to, something to\r\n      make the rest of life worth while, something to leave himself to,\r\n      some perpetuity of self. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I had a son,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought bitterly,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9ca proper legal son, I could make shift to go on as I used. One\r\n      woman\xe2\x80\x99s much the same as another, after all.\xe2\x80\x9d But as he walked he\r\n      shook his head. No! One woman was not the same as another. Many a\r\n      time had he tried to think that in the old days of his thwarted\r\n      married life; and he had always failed. He was failing now. He\r\n      was trying to think Annette the same as that other. But she was\r\n      not, she had not the lure of that old passion. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Irene\xe2\x80\x99s my\r\n      wife,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cmy legal wife. I have done nothing to put her\r\n      away from me. Why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t she come back to me? It\xe2\x80\x99s the right\r\n      thing, the lawful thing. It makes no scandal, no disturbance. If\r\n      it\xe2\x80\x99s disagreeable to her\xe2\x80\x94but why _should_ it be? I\xe2\x80\x99m not a leper,\r\n      and she\xe2\x80\x94she\xe2\x80\x99s no longer in love!\xe2\x80\x9d Why should he be put to the\r\n      shifts and the sordid disgraces and the lurking defeats of the\r\n      Divorce Court, when there she was like an empty house only\r\n      waiting to be retaken into use and possession by him who legally\r\n      owned her? To one so secretive as Soames the thought of reentry\r\n      into quiet possession of his own property with nothing given away\r\n      to the world was intensely alluring. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he mused, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m glad I\r\n      went to see that girl. I know now what I want most. If only Irene\r\n      will come back I\xe2\x80\x99ll be as considerate as she wishes; she could\r\n      live her own life; but perhaps\xe2\x80\x94perhaps she would come round to\r\n      me.\xe2\x80\x9d There was a lump in his throat. And doggedly along by the\r\n      railings of the Green Park, towards his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, he went,\r\n      trying to tread on his shadow walking before him in the brilliant\r\n      moonlight.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      PART II\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER I THE THIRD GENERATION\r\n\r\n\r\n      Jolly Forsyte was strolling down High Street, Oxford, on a\r\n      November afternoon; Val Dartie was strolling up. Jolly had just\r\n      changed out of boating flannels and was on his way to the\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cFrying-pan,\xe2\x80\x9d to which he had recently been elected. Val had just\r\n      changed out of riding clothes and was on his way to the fire\xe2\x80\x94a\r\n      bookmaker\xe2\x80\x99s in Cornmarket.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHallo!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Val.\r\n\r\n      The cousins had met but twice, Jolly, the second-year man, having\r\n      invited the freshman to breakfast; and last evening they had seen\r\n      each other again under somewhat exotic circumstances.\r\n\r\n      Over a tailor\xe2\x80\x99s in the Cornmarket resided one of those privileged\r\n      young beings called minors, whose inheritances are large, whose\r\n      parents are dead, whose guardians are remote, and whose instincts\r\n      are vicious. At nineteen he had commenced one of those careers\r\n      attractive and inexplicable to ordinary mortals for whom a single\r\n      bankruptcy is good as a feast. Already famous for having the only\r\n      roulette table then to be found in Oxford, he was anticipating\r\n      his expectations at a dazzling rate. He out-crummed Crum, though\r\n      of a sanguine and rather beefy type which lacked the latter\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      fascinating languor. For Val it had been in the nature of baptism\r\n      to be taken there to play roulette; in the nature of confirmation\r\n      to get back into college, after hours, through a window whose\r\n      bars were deceptive. Once, during that evening of delight,\r\n      glancing up from the seductive green before him, he had caught\r\n      sight, through a cloud of smoke, of his cousin standing opposite.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c_Rouge gagne, impair, et manque!_\xe2\x80\x9d He had not seen him again.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cCome in to the Frying-pan and have tea,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly, and they\r\n      went in.\r\n\r\n      A stranger, seeing them together, would have noticed an\r\n      unseizable resemblance between these second cousins of the third\r\n      generations of Forsytes; the same bone formation in face, though\r\n      Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s eyes were darker grey, his hair lighter and more wavy.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTea and buttered buns, waiter, please,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHave one of my cigarettes?\xe2\x80\x9d said Val. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw you last night. How\r\n      did you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t play.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI won fifteen quid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Though desirous of repeating a whimsical comment on gambling he\r\n      had once heard his father make\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you\xe2\x80\x99re fleeced you\xe2\x80\x99re sick,\r\n      and when you fleece you\xe2\x80\x99re sorry\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Jolly contented himself with:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cRotten game, I think; I was at school with that chap. He\xe2\x80\x99s an\r\n      awful fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val, as one might speak in defence of a\r\n      disparaged god; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty good sport.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      They exchanged whiffs in silence.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou met my people, didn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re coming up\r\n      to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val grew a little red.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cReally! I can give you a rare good tip for the Manchester\r\n      November handicap.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThanks, I only take interest in the classic races.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t make any money over them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI hate the ring,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly; \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s such a row and stink. I\r\n      like the paddock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI like to back my judgment,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Val.\r\n\r\n      Jolly smiled; his smile was like his father\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t got any. I always lose money if I bet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou have to buy experience, of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, but it\xe2\x80\x99s all messed-up with doing people in the eye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOf course, or they\xe2\x80\x99ll do you\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the excitement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly looked a little scornful.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you do with yourself? Row?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94ride, and drive about. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to play polo next term, if I\r\n      can get my granddad to stump up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s old Uncle James, isn\xe2\x80\x99t it? What\xe2\x80\x99s he like?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOlder than forty hills,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val, \xe2\x80\x9cand always thinking he\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      going to be ruined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose my granddad and he were brothers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe any of that old lot were sportsmen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val;\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cthey must have worshipped money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMine didn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly warmly.\r\n\r\n      Val flipped the ash off his cigarette.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMoney\xe2\x80\x99s only fit to spend,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish the deuce I had\r\n      more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly gave him that direct upward look of judgment which he had\r\n      inherited from old Jolyon: One didn\xe2\x80\x99t talk about money! And again\r\n      there was silence, while they drank tea and ate the buttered\r\n      buns.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhere are your people going to stay?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Val, elaborately\r\n      casual.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Rainbow.\xe2\x80\x99 What do you think of the war?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cRotten, so far. The Boers aren\xe2\x80\x99t sports a bit. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t they\r\n      come out into the open?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy should they? They\xe2\x80\x99ve got everything against them except\r\n      their way of fighting. I rather admire them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThey can ride and shoot,\xe2\x80\x9d admitted Val, \xe2\x80\x9cbut they\xe2\x80\x99re a lousy\r\n      lot. Do you know Crum?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOf Merton? Only by sight. He\xe2\x80\x99s in that fast set too, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\r\n      Rather La-di-da and Brummagem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val said fixedly: \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a friend of mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! Sorry!\xe2\x80\x9d And they sat awkwardly staring past each other,\r\n      having pitched on their pet points of snobbery. For Jolly was\r\n      forming himself unconsciously on a set whose motto was:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe defy you to bore us. Life isn\xe2\x80\x99t half long enough, and we\xe2\x80\x99re\r\n      going to talk faster and more crisply, do more and know more, and\r\n      dwell less on any subject than you can possibly imagine. We are\r\n      \xe2\x80\x98the best\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94made of wire and whipcord.\xe2\x80\x9d And Val was unconsciously\r\n      forming himself on a set whose motto was: \xe2\x80\x9cWe defy you to\r\n      interest or excite us. We have had every sensation, or if we\r\n      haven\xe2\x80\x99t, we pretend we have. We are so exhausted with living that\r\n      no hours are too small for us. We will lose our shirts with\r\n      equanimity. We have flown fast and are past everything. All is\r\n      cigarette smoke. Bismillah!\xe2\x80\x9d Competitive spirit, bone-deep in the\r\n      English, was obliging those two young Forsytes to have ideals;\r\n      and at the close of a century ideals are mixed. The aristocracy\r\n      had already in the main adopted the \xe2\x80\x9cjumping-Jesus\xe2\x80\x9d principle;\r\n      though here and there one like Crum\xe2\x80\x94who was an \xe2\x80\x9chonourable\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94stood\r\n      starkly languid for that gambler\xe2\x80\x99s Nirvana which had been the\r\n      _summum bonum_ of the old \xe2\x80\x9cdandies\xe2\x80\x9d and of \xe2\x80\x9cthe mashers\xe2\x80\x9d in the\r\n      eighties. And round Crum were still gathered a forlorn hope of\r\n      blue-bloods with a plutocratic following.\r\n\r\n      But there was between the cousins another far less obvious\r\n      antipathy\xe2\x80\x94coming from the unseizable family resemblance, which\r\n      each perhaps resented; or from some half-consciousness of that\r\n      old feud persisting still between their branches of the clan,\r\n      formed within them by odd words or half-hints dropped by their\r\n      elders. And Jolly, tinkling his teaspoon, was musing: \xe2\x80\x9cHis\r\n      tie-pin and his waistcoat and his drawl and his betting\xe2\x80\x94good\r\n      Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And Val, finishing his bun, was thinking: \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s rather a young\r\n      beast!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose you\xe2\x80\x99ll be meeting your people?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, getting up.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI wish you\xe2\x80\x99d tell them I should like to show them over\r\n      B.N.C.\xe2\x80\x94not that there\xe2\x80\x99s anything much there\xe2\x80\x94if they\xe2\x80\x99d care to\r\n      come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThanks, I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWould they lunch? I\xe2\x80\x99ve got rather a decent scout.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly doubted if they would have time.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ll ask them, though?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cVery good of you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly, fully meaning that they should\r\n      not go; but, instinctively polite, he added: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99d better come\r\n      and have dinner with us to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cRather. What time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cSeven-thirty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d And they parted, a subtle antagonism alive within them.\r\n\r\n      Holly and her father arrived by a midday train. It was her first\r\n      visit to the city of spires and dreams, and she was very silent,\r\n      looking almost shyly at the brother who was part of this\r\n      wonderful place. After lunch she wandered, examining his\r\n      household gods with intense curiosity. Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s sitting-room was\r\n      panelled, and Art represented by a set of Bartolozzi prints which\r\n      had belonged to old Jolyon, and by college photographs\xe2\x80\x94of young\r\n      men, live young men, a little heroic, and to be compared with her\r\n      memories of Val. Jolyon also scrutinised with care that evidence\r\n      of his boy\xe2\x80\x99s character and tastes.\r\n\r\n      Jolly was anxious that they should see him rowing, so they set\r\n      forth to the river. Holly, between her brother and her father,\r\n      felt elated when heads were turned and eyes rested on her. That\r\n      they might see him to the best advantage they left him at the\r\n      Barge and crossed the river to the towing-path. Slight in\r\n      build\xe2\x80\x94for of all the Forsytes only old Swithin and George were\r\n      beefy\xe2\x80\x94Jolly was rowing \xe2\x80\x9cTwo\xe2\x80\x9d in a trial eight. He looked very\r\n      earnest and strenuous. With pride Jolyon thought him the\r\n      best-looking boy of the lot; Holly, as became a sister, was more\r\n      struck by one or two of the others, but would not have said so\r\n      for the world. The river was bright that afternoon, the meadows\r\n      lush, the trees still beautiful with colour. Distinguished peace\r\n      clung around the old city; Jolyon promised himself a day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      sketching if the weather held. The Eight passed a second time,\r\n      spurting home along the Barges\xe2\x80\x94Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s face was very set, so as\r\n      not to show that he was blown. They returned across the river and\r\n      waited for him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly in the Christ Church meadows, \xe2\x80\x9cI had to ask that\r\n      chap Val Dartie to dine with us to-night. He wanted to give you\r\n      lunch and show you B.N.C., so I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d better; then you\r\n      needn\xe2\x80\x99t go. I don\xe2\x80\x99t like him much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly\xe2\x80\x99s rather sallow face had become suffused with pink.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. He seems to me rather showy and bad form. What\r\n      are his people like, Dad? He\xe2\x80\x99s only a second cousin, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon took refuge in a smile.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAsk Holly,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cshe saw his uncle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI _liked_ Val,\xe2\x80\x9d Holly answered, staring at the ground before\r\n      her; \xe2\x80\x9chis uncle looked\xe2\x80\x94awfully different.\xe2\x80\x9d She stole a glance at\r\n      Jolly from under her lashes.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon with whimsical intention, \xe2\x80\x9chear our\r\n      family history, my dears? It\xe2\x80\x99s quite a fairy tale. The first\r\n      Jolyon Forsyte\xe2\x80\x94at all events the first we know anything of, and\r\n      that would be your great-great-grandfather\xe2\x80\x94dwelt in the land of\r\n      Dorset on the edge of the sea, being by profession an\r\n      \xe2\x80\x98agriculturalist,\xe2\x80\x99 as your great-aunt put it, and the son of an\r\n      agriculturist\xe2\x80\x94farmers, in fact; your grandfather used to call\r\n      them, \xe2\x80\x98Very small beer.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d He looked at Jolly to see how his\r\n      lordliness was standing it, and with the other eye noted Holly\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      malicious pleasure in the slight drop of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe may suppose him thick and sturdy, standing for England as it\r\n      was before the Industrial Era began. The second Jolyon\r\n      Forsyte\xe2\x80\x94your great-grandfather, Jolly; better known as Superior\r\n      Dosset Forsyte\xe2\x80\x94built houses, so the chronicle runs, begat ten\r\n      children, and migrated to London town. It is known that he drank\r\n      sherry. We may suppose him representing the England of Napoleon\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      wars, and general unrest. The eldest of his six sons was the\r\n      third Jolyon, your grandfather, my dears\xe2\x80\x94tea merchant and\r\n      chairman of companies, one of the soundest Englishmen who ever\r\n      lived\xe2\x80\x94and to me the dearest.\xe2\x80\x9d Jolyon\xe2\x80\x99s voice had lost its irony,\r\n      and his son and daughter gazed at him solemnly, \xe2\x80\x9cHe was just and\r\n      tenacious, tender and young at heart. You remember him, and I\r\n      remember him. Pass to the others! Your great-uncle James, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      young Val\xe2\x80\x99s grandfather, had a son called Soames\xe2\x80\x94whereby hangs a\r\n      tale of no love lost, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell it you. James\r\n      and the other eight children of \xe2\x80\x98Superior Dosset,\xe2\x80\x99 of whom there\r\n      are still five alive, may be said to have represented Victorian\r\n      England, with its principles of trade and individualism at five\r\n      per cent. and your money back\xe2\x80\x94if you know what that means. At all\r\n      events they\xe2\x80\x99ve turned thirty thousand pounds into a cool million\r\n      between them in the course of their long lives. They never did a\r\n      wild thing\xe2\x80\x94unless it was your great-uncle Swithin, who I believe\r\n      was once swindled at thimble-rig, and was called \xe2\x80\x98Four-in-hand\r\n      Forsyte\xe2\x80\x99 because he drove a pair. Their day is passing, and their\r\n      type, not altogether for the advantage of the country. They were\r\n      pedestrian, but they too were sound. I am the fourth Jolyon\r\n      Forsyte\xe2\x80\x94a poor holder of the name\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo, Dad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly, and Holly squeezed his hand.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9ca poor specimen, representing, I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\n      afraid, nothing but the end of the century, unearned income,\r\n      amateurism, and individual liberty\xe2\x80\x94a different thing from\r\n      individualism, Jolly. You are the fifth Jolyon Forsyte, old man,\r\n      and you open the ball of the new century.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      As he spoke they turned in through the college gates, and Holly\r\n      said: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s fascinating, Dad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      None of them quite knew what she meant. Jolly was grave.\r\n\r\n      The Rainbow, distinguished, as only an Oxford hostel can be, for\r\n      lack of modernity, provided one small oak-panelled private\r\n      sitting-room, in which Holly sat to receive, white-frocked, shy,\r\n      and alone, when the only guest arrived. Rather as one would touch\r\n      a moth, Val took her hand. And wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t she wear this \xe2\x80\x9cmeasly\r\n      flower\xe2\x80\x9d. It would look ripping in her hair. He removed a gardenia\r\n      from his coat.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! No, thank you\xe2\x80\x94I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d But she took it and pinned it at\r\n      her neck, having suddenly remembered that word \xe2\x80\x9cshowy\xe2\x80\x9d. Val\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      buttonhole would give offence; and she so much wanted Jolly to\r\n      like him. Did she realise that Val was at his best and quietest\r\n      in her presence, and was that, perhaps, half the secret of his\r\n      attraction for her?\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI never said anything about our ride, Val.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cRather not! It\xe2\x80\x99s just between us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      By the uneasiness of his hands and the fidgeting of his feet he\r\n      was giving her a sense of power very delicious; a soft feeling\r\n      too\xe2\x80\x94the wish to make him happy.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDo tell me about Oxford. It must be ever so lovely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val admitted that it was frightfully decent to do what you liked;\r\n      the lectures were nothing; and there were some very good chaps.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOnly,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cof course I wish I was in town, and could come\r\n      down and see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly moved one hand shyly on her knee, and her glance dropped.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou haven\xe2\x80\x99t forgotten,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, suddenly gathering courage,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cthat we\xe2\x80\x99re going mad-rabbiting together?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly smiled.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! That was only make-believe. One can\xe2\x80\x99t do that sort of thing\r\n      after one\xe2\x80\x99s grown up, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDash it! cousins can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val. \xe2\x80\x9cNext Long Vac.\xe2\x80\x94it begins in\r\n      June, you know, and goes on for ever\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ll watch our chance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      But, though the thrill of conspiracy ran through her veins, Holly\r\n      shook her head. \xe2\x80\x9cIt won\xe2\x80\x99t come off,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t it!\xe2\x80\x9d said Val fervently; \xe2\x80\x9cwho\xe2\x80\x99s going to stop it? Not your\r\n      father or your brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At this moment Jolyon and Jolly came in; and romance fled into\r\n      Val\xe2\x80\x99s patent leather and Holly\xe2\x80\x99s white satin toes, where it\r\n      itched and tingled during an evening not conspicuous for\r\n      open-heartedness.\r\n\r\n      Sensitive to atmosphere, Jolyon soon felt the latent antagonism\r\n      between the boys, and was puzzled by Holly; so he became\r\n      unconsciously ironical, which is fatal to the expansiveness of\r\n      youth. A letter, handed to him after dinner, reduced him to a\r\n      silence hardly broken till Jolly and Val rose to go. He went out\r\n      with them, smoking his cigar, and walked with his son to the\r\n      gates of Christ Church. Turning back, he took out the letter and\r\n      read it again beneath a lamp.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDEAR JOLYON,\r\n          \xe2\x80\x9cSoames came again to-night\xe2\x80\x94my thirty-seventh birthday. You\r\n          were right, I mustn\xe2\x80\x99t stay here. I\xe2\x80\x99m going to-morrow to the\r\n          Piedmont Hotel, but I won\xe2\x80\x99t go abroad without seeing you. I\r\n          feel lonely and down-hearted.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYours affectionately,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIRENE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He folded the letter back into his pocket and walked on,\r\n      astonished at the violence of his feelings. What had the fellow\r\n      said or done?\r\n\r\n      He turned into High Street, down the Turf, and on among a maze of\r\n      spires and domes and long college fronts and walls, bright or\r\n      dark-shadowed in the strong moonlight. In this very heart of\r\n      England\xe2\x80\x99s gentility it was difficult to realise that a lonely\r\n      woman could be importuned or hunted, but what else could her\r\n      letter mean? Soames must have been pressing her to go back to him\r\n      again, with public opinion and the Law on his side, too!\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cEighteen-ninety-nine!,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, gazing at the broken glass\r\n      shining on the top of a villa garden wall; \xe2\x80\x9cbut when it comes to\r\n      property we\xe2\x80\x99re still a heathen people! I\xe2\x80\x99ll go up to-morrow\r\n      morning. I dare say it\xe2\x80\x99ll be best for her to go abroad.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet the\r\n      thought displeased him. Why should Soames hunt her out of\r\n      England! Besides, he might follow, and out there she would be\r\n      still more helpless against the attentions of her own husband! \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      must tread warily,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; \xe2\x80\x9cthat fellow could make himself\r\n      very nasty. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t like his manner in the cab the other night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      His thoughts turned to his daughter June. Could she help? Once on\r\n      a time Irene had been her greatest friend, and now she was a\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9clame duck,\xe2\x80\x9d such as must appeal to June\xe2\x80\x99s nature! He determined\r\n      to wire to his daughter to meet him at Paddington Station.\r\n      Retracing his steps towards the Rainbow he questioned his own\r\n      sensations. Would he be upsetting himself over every woman in\r\n      like case? No! he would not. The candour of this conclusion\r\n      discomfited him; and, finding that Holly had gone up to bed, he\r\n      sought his own room. But he could not sleep, and sat for a long\r\n      time at his window, huddled in an overcoat, watching the\r\n      moonlight on the roofs.\r\n\r\n      Next door Holly too was awake, thinking of the lashes above and\r\n      below Val\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, especially below; and of what she could do to\r\n      make Jolly like him better. The scent of the gardenia was strong\r\n      in her little bedroom, and pleasant to her.\r\n\r\n      And Val, leaning out of his first-floor window in B.N.C., was\r\n      gazing at a moonlit quadrangle without seeing it at all, seeing\r\n      instead Holly, slim and white-frocked, as she sat beside the fire\r\n      when he first went in.\r\n\r\n      But Jolly, in his bedroom narrow as a ghost, lay with a hand\r\n      beneath his cheek and dreamed he was with Val in one boat, rowing\r\n      a race against him, while his father was calling from the\r\n      towpath: \xe2\x80\x9cTwo! Get your hands away there, bless you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER II SOAMES PUTS IT TO THE TOUCH\r\n\r\n\r\n      Of all those radiant firms which emblazon with their windows the\r\n      West End of London, Gaves and Cortegal were considered by Soames\r\n      the most \xe2\x80\x9cattractive\xe2\x80\x9d word just coming into fashion. He had never\r\n      had his Uncle Swithin\xe2\x80\x99s taste in precious stones, and the\r\n      abandonment by Irene when she left his house in 1887 of all the\r\n      glittering things he had given her had disgusted him with this\r\n      form of investment. But he still knew a diamond when he saw one,\r\n      and during the week before her birthday he had taken occasion, on\r\n      his way into the Poultry or his way out therefrom, to dally a\r\n      little before the greater jewellers where one got, if not one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      money\xe2\x80\x99s worth, at least a certain cachet with the goods.\r\n\r\n      Constant cogitation since his drive with Jolyon had convinced him\r\n      more and more of the supreme importance of this moment in his\r\n      life, the supreme need for taking steps and those not wrong. And,\r\n      alongside the dry and reasoned sense that it was now or never\r\n      with his self-preservation, now or never if he were to range\r\n      himself and found a family, went the secret urge of his senses\r\n      roused by the sight of her who had once been a passionately\r\n      desired wife, and the conviction that it was a sin against common\r\n      sense and the decent secrecy of Forsytes to waste the wife he\r\n      had.\r\n\r\n      In an opinion on Winifred\xe2\x80\x99s case, Dreamer, Q.C.\xe2\x80\x94he would much\r\n      have preferred Waterbuck, but they had made him a judge (so late\r\n      in the day as to rouse the usual suspicion of a political\r\n      job)\xe2\x80\x94had advised that they should go forward and obtain\r\n      restitution of conjugal rights, a point which to Soames had never\r\n      been in doubt. When they had obtained a decree to that effect\r\n      they must wait to see if it was obeyed. If not, it would\r\n      constitute legal desertion, and they should obtain evidence of\r\n      misconduct and file their petition for divorce. All of which\r\n      Soames knew perfectly well. They had marked him ten and one. This\r\n      simplicity in his sister\xe2\x80\x99s case only made him the more desperate\r\n      about the difficulty in his own. Everything, in fact, was driving\r\n      him towards the simple solution of Irene\xe2\x80\x99s return. If it were\r\n      still against the grain with her, had _he_ not feelings to\r\n      subdue, injury to forgive, pain to forget? He at least had never\r\n      injured her, and this was a world of compromise! He could offer\r\n      her so much more than she had now. He would be prepared to make a\r\n      liberal settlement on her which could not be upset. He often\r\n      scrutinised his image in these days. He had never been a peacock\r\n      like that fellow Dartie, or fancied himself a woman\xe2\x80\x99s man, but he\r\n      had a certain belief in his own appearance\xe2\x80\x94not unjustly, for it\r\n      was well-coupled and preserved, neat, healthy, pale, unblemished\r\n      by drink or excess of any kind. The Forsyte jaw and the\r\n      concentration of his face were, in his eyes, virtues. So far as\r\n      he could tell there was no feature of him which need inspire\r\n      dislike.\r\n\r\n      Thoughts and yearnings, with which one lives daily, become\r\n      natural, even if far-fetched in their inception. If he could only\r\n      give tangible proof enough of his determination to let bygones be\r\n      bygones, and to do all in his power to please her, why should she\r\n      not come back to him?\r\n\r\n      He entered Gaves and Cortegal\xe2\x80\x99s therefore, on the morning of\r\n      November the 9th, to buy a certain diamond brooch. \xe2\x80\x9cFour\r\n      twenty-five and dirt cheap, sir, at the money. It\xe2\x80\x99s a lady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      brooch.\xe2\x80\x9d There was that in his mood which made him accept without\r\n      demur. And he went on into the Poultry with the flat green\r\n      morocco case in his breast pocket. Several times that day he\r\n      opened it to look at the seven soft shining stones in their\r\n      velvet oval nest.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIf the lady doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like it, sir, happy to exchange it any time.\r\n      But there\xe2\x80\x99s no fear of that.\xe2\x80\x9d If only there were not! He got\r\n      through a vast amount of work, only soother of the nerves he\r\n      knew. A cablegram came while he was in the office with details\r\n      from the agent in Buenos Aires, and the name and address of a\r\n      stewardess who would be prepared to swear to what was necessary.\r\n      It was a timely spur to Soames, with his rooted distaste for the\r\n      washing of dirty linen in public. And when he set forth by\r\n      Underground to Victoria Station he received a fresh impetus\r\n      towards the renewal of his married life from the account in his\r\n      evening paper of a fashionable divorce suit. The homing instinct\r\n      of all true Forsytes in anxiety and trouble, the corporate\r\n      tendency which kept them strong and solid, made him choose to\r\n      dine at Park Lane. He neither could nor would breathe a word to\r\n      his people of his intention\xe2\x80\x94too reticent and proud\xe2\x80\x94but the\r\n      thought that at least they would be glad if they knew, and wish\r\n      him luck, was heartening.\r\n\r\n      James was in lugubrious mood, for the fire which the impudence of\r\n      Kruger\xe2\x80\x99s ultimatum had lit in him had been cold-watered by the\r\n      poor success of the last month, and the exhortations to effort in\r\n      _The Times_. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t know where it would end. Soames sought to\r\n      cheer him by the continual use of the word Buller. But James\r\n      couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell! There was Colley\xe2\x80\x94and he got stuck on that hill,\r\n      and this Ladysmith was down in a hollow, and altogether it looked\r\n      to him a \xe2\x80\x9cpretty kettle of fish\xe2\x80\x9d; he thought they ought to be\r\n      sending the sailors\xe2\x80\x94they were the chaps, they did a lot of good\r\n      in the Crimea. Soames shifted the ground of consolation. Winifred\r\n      had heard from Val that there had been a \xe2\x80\x9crag\xe2\x80\x9d and a bonfire on\r\n      Guy Fawkes Day at Oxford, and that he had escaped detection by\r\n      blacking his face.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d James muttered, \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a clever little chap.\xe2\x80\x9d But he shook\r\n      his head shortly afterwards and remarked that he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what\r\n      would become of him, and looking wistfully at his son, murmured\r\n      on that Soames had never had a boy. He would have liked a\r\n      grandson of his own name. And now\xe2\x80\x94well, there it was!\r\n\r\n      Soames flinched. He had not expected such a challenge to disclose\r\n      the secret in his heart. And Emily, who saw him wince, said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, James; don\xe2\x80\x99t talk like that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      But James, not looking anyone in the face, muttered on. There\r\n      were Roger and Nicholas and Jolyon; they all had grandsons. And\r\n      Swithin and Timothy had never married. He had done his best; but\r\n      he would soon be gone now. And, as though he had uttered words of\r\n      profound consolation, he was silent, eating brains with a fork\r\n      and a piece of bread, and swallowing the bread.\r\n\r\n      Soames excused himself directly after dinner. It was not really\r\n      cold, but he put on his fur coat, which served to fortify him\r\n      against the fits of nervous shivering to which he had been\r\n      subject all day. Subconsciously, he knew that he looked better\r\n      thus than in an ordinary black overcoat. Then, feeling the\r\n      morocco case flat against his heart, he sallied forth. He was no\r\n      smoker, but he lit a cigarette, and smoked it gingerly as he\r\n      walked along. He moved slowly down the Row towards Knightsbridge,\r\n      timing himself to get to Chelsea at nine-fifteen. What did she do\r\n      with herself evening after evening in that little hole? How\r\n      mysterious women were! One lived alongside and knew nothing of\r\n      them. What could she have seen in that fellow Bosinney to send\r\n      her mad? For there was madness after all in what she had\r\n      done\xe2\x80\x94crazy moonstruck madness, in which all sense of values had\r\n      been lost, and her life and his life ruined! And for a moment he\r\n      was filled with a sort of exaltation, as though he were a man\r\n      read of in a story who, possessed by the Christian spirit, would\r\n      restore to her all the prizes of existence, forgiving and\r\n      forgetting, and becoming the godfather of her future. Under a\r\n      tree opposite Knightsbridge Barracks, where the moonlight struck\r\n      down clear and white, he took out once more the morocco case, and\r\n      let the beams draw colour from those stones. Yes, they were of\r\n      the first water! But, at the hard closing snap of the case,\r\n      another cold shiver ran through his nerves; and he walked on\r\n      faster, clenching his gloved hands in the pockets of his coat,\r\n      almost hoping she would not be in. The thought of how mysterious\r\n      she was again beset him. Dining alone there night after night\xe2\x80\x94in\r\n      an evening dress, too, as if she were making believe to be in\r\n      society! Playing the piano\xe2\x80\x94to herself! Not even a dog or cat, so\r\n      far as he had seen. And that reminded him suddenly of the mare he\r\n      kept for station work at Mapledurham. If ever he went to the\r\n      stable, there she was quite alone, half asleep, and yet, on her\r\n      home journeys going more freely than on her way out, as if\r\n      longing to be back and lonely in her stable! \xe2\x80\x9cI would treat her\r\n      well,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought incoherently. \xe2\x80\x9cI would be very careful.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\n      all that capacity for home life of which a mocking Fate seemed\r\n      for ever to have deprived him swelled suddenly in Soames, so that\r\n      he dreamed dreams opposite South Kensington Station. In the\r\n      King\xe2\x80\x99s Road a man came slithering out of a public house playing a\r\n      concertina. Soames watched him for a moment dance crazily on the\r\n      pavement to his own drawling jagged sounds, then crossed over to\r\n      avoid contact with this piece of drunken foolery. A night in the\r\n      lock-up! What asses people were! But the man had noticed his\r\n      movement of avoidance, and streams of genial blasphemy followed\r\n      him across the street. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope they\xe2\x80\x99ll run him in,\xe2\x80\x9d thought\r\n      Soames viciously. \xe2\x80\x9cTo have ruffians like that about, with women\r\n      out alone!\xe2\x80\x9d A woman\xe2\x80\x99s figure in front had induced this thought.\r\n      Her walk seemed oddly familiar, and when she turned the corner\r\n      for which he was bound, his heart began to beat. He hastened on\r\n      to the corner to make certain. Yes! It was Irene; he could not\r\n      mistake her walk in that little drab street. She threaded two\r\n      more turnings, and from the last corner he saw her enter her\r\n      block of flats. To make sure of her now, he ran those few paces,\r\n      hurried up the stairs, and caught her standing at her door. He\r\n      heard the latchkey in the lock, and reached her side just as she\r\n      turned round, startled, in the open doorway.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, breathless. \xe2\x80\x9cI happened to see you.\r\n      Let me come in a minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      She had put her hand up to her breast, her face was colourless,\r\n      her eyes widened by alarm. Then seeming to master herself, she\r\n      inclined her head, and said: \xe2\x80\x9cVery well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames closed the door. He, too, had need to recover, and when\r\n      she had passed into the sitting-room, waited a full minute,\r\n      taking deep breaths to still the beating of his heart. At this\r\n      moment, so fraught with the future, to take out that morocco case\r\n      seemed crude. Yet, not to take it out left him there before her\r\n      with no preliminary excuse for coming. And in this dilemma he was\r\n      seized with impatience at all this paraphernalia of excuse and\r\n      justification. This was a scene\xe2\x80\x94it could be nothing else, and he\r\n      must face it. He heard her voice, uncomfortably, pathetically\r\n      soft:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy have you come again? Didn\xe2\x80\x99t you understand that I would\r\n      rather you did not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He noticed her clothes\xe2\x80\x94a dark brown velvet corduroy, a sable boa,\r\n      a small round toque of the same. They suited her admirably. She\r\n      had money to spare for dress, evidently! He said abruptly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s your birthday. I brought you this,\xe2\x80\x9d and he held out to her\r\n      the green morocco case.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! No-no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames pressed the clasp; the seven stones gleamed out on the\r\n      pale grey velvet.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cJust as a sign that you don\xe2\x80\x99t bear me\r\n      ill-feeling any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI couldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames took it out of the case.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLet me just see how it looks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      She shrank back.\r\n\r\n      He followed, thrusting his hand with the brooch in it against the\r\n      front of her dress. She shrank again.\r\n\r\n      Soames dropped his hand.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIrene,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9clet bygones be bygones. If _I_ can, surely you\r\n      might. Let\xe2\x80\x99s begin again, as if nothing had been. Won\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d His\r\n      voice was wistful, and his eyes, resting on her face, had in them\r\n      a sort of supplication.\r\n\r\n      She, who was standing literally with her back against the wall,\r\n      gave a little gulp, and that was all her answer. Soames went on:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cCan you really want to live all your days half-dead in this\r\n      little hole? Come back to me, and I\xe2\x80\x99ll give you all you want. You\r\n      shall live your own life; I swear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He saw her face quiver ironically.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I mean it this time. I\xe2\x80\x99ll only ask one\r\n      thing. I just want\xe2\x80\x94I just want a son. Don\xe2\x80\x99t look like that! I\r\n      want one. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard.\xe2\x80\x9d His voice had grown hurried, so that he\r\n      hardly knew it for his own, and twice he jerked his head back as\r\n      if struggling for breath. It was the sight of her eyes fixed on\r\n      him, dark with a sort of fascinated fright, which pulled him\r\n      together and changed that painful incoherence to anger.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIs it so very unnatural?\xe2\x80\x9d he said between his teeth, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it\r\n      unnatural to want a child from one\xe2\x80\x99s own wife? You wrecked our\r\n      life and put this blight on everything. We go on only half alive,\r\n      and without any future. Is it so very unflattering to you that in\r\n      spite of everything I\xe2\x80\x94I still want you for my wife? Speak, for\r\n      Goodness\xe2\x80\x99 sake! do speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Irene seemed to try, but did not succeed.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to frighten you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Soames more gently. \xe2\x80\x9cHeaven\r\n      knows. I only want you to see that I can\xe2\x80\x99t go on like this. I\r\n      want you back. I want you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Irene raised one hand and covered the lower part of her face, but\r\n      her eyes never moved from his, as though she trusted in them to\r\n      keep him at bay. And all those years, barren and bitter,\r\n      since\xe2\x80\x94ah! when?\xe2\x80\x94almost since he had first known her, surged up in\r\n      one great wave of recollection in Soames; and a spasm that for\r\n      his life he could not control constricted his face.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not too late,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s not\xe2\x80\x94if you\xe2\x80\x99ll only believe\r\n      it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Irene uncovered her lips, and both her hands made a writhing\r\n      gesture in front of her breast. Soames seized them.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t!\xe2\x80\x9d she said under her breath. But he stood holding on to\r\n      them, trying to stare into her eyes which did not waver. Then she\r\n      said quietly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI am alone here. You won\xe2\x80\x99t behave again as you once behaved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Dropping her hands as though they had been hot irons, he turned\r\n      away. Was it possible that there could be such relentless\r\n      unforgiveness! Could that one act of violent possession be still\r\n      alive within her? Did it bar him thus utterly? And doggedly he\r\n      said, without looking up:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI am not going till you\xe2\x80\x99ve answered me. I am offering what few\r\n      men would bring themselves to offer, I want a\xe2\x80\x94a reasonable\r\n      answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And almost with surprise he heard her say:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t have a reasonable answer. Reason has nothing to do\r\n      with it. You can only have the brutal truth: I would rather die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames stared at her.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. And there intervened in him a sort of paralysis of\r\n      speech and movement, the kind of quivering which comes when a man\r\n      has received a deadly insult, and does not yet know how he is\r\n      going to take it, or rather what it is going to do with him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d he said again, \xe2\x80\x9cas bad as that? Indeed! You would rather\r\n      die. That\xe2\x80\x99s pretty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry. You wanted me to answer. I can\xe2\x80\x99t help the truth, can\r\n      I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      At that queer spiritual appeal Soames turned for relief to\r\n      actuality. He snapped the brooch back into its case and put it in\r\n      his pocket.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThe truth!\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s no such thing with women. It\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      nerves\xe2\x80\x94nerves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He heard the whisper:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes; nerves don\xe2\x80\x99t lie. Haven\xe2\x80\x99t you discovered that?\xe2\x80\x9d He was\r\n      silent, obsessed by the thought: \xe2\x80\x9cI _will_ hate this woman. I\r\n      _will_ hate her.\xe2\x80\x9d That was the trouble! If only he could! He shot\r\n      a glance at her who stood unmoving against the wall with her head\r\n      up and her hands clasped, for all the world as if she were going\r\n      to be shot. And he said quickly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t believe a word of it. You have a lover. If you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t,\r\n      you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be such a\xe2\x80\x94such a little idiot.\xe2\x80\x9d He was conscious,\r\n      before the expression in her eyes, that he had uttered something\r\n      of a non-sequitur, and dropped back too abruptly into the verbal\r\n      freedom of his connubial days. He turned away to the door. But he\r\n      could not go out. Something within him\xe2\x80\x94that most deep and secret\r\n      Forsyte quality, the impossibility of letting go, the\r\n      impossibility of seeing the fantastic and forlorn nature of his\r\n      own tenacity\xe2\x80\x94prevented him. He turned about again, and there\r\n      stood, with his back against the door, as hers was against the\r\n      wall opposite, quite unconscious of anything ridiculous in this\r\n      separation by the whole width of the room.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDo you ever think of anybody but yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      Irene\xe2\x80\x99s lips quivered; then she answered slowly:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDo you ever think that I found out my mistake\xe2\x80\x94my hopeless,\r\n      terrible mistake\xe2\x80\x94the very first week of our marriage; that I went\r\n      on trying three years\xe2\x80\x94you know I went on trying? Was it for\r\n      myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Soames gritted his teeth. \xe2\x80\x9cGod knows what it was. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never\r\n      understood you; I shall never understand you. You had everything\r\n      you wanted; and you can have it again, and more. What\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\n      matter with me? I ask you a plain question: What is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      Unconscious of the pathos in that enquiry, he went on\r\n      passionately: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not lame, I\xe2\x80\x99m not loathsome, I\xe2\x80\x99m not a boor,\r\n      I\xe2\x80\x99m not a fool. What is it? What\xe2\x80\x99s the mystery about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Her answer was a long sigh.\r\n\r\n      He clasped his hands with a gesture that for him was strangely\r\n      full of expression. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I came here to-night I was\xe2\x80\x94I hoped\xe2\x80\x94I\r\n      meant everything that I could to do away with the past, and start\r\n      fair again. And you meet me with \xe2\x80\x98nerves,\xe2\x80\x99 and silence, and\r\n      sighs. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing tangible. It\xe2\x80\x99s like\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s like a spider\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      web.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      That whisper from across the room maddened Soames afresh.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I don\xe2\x80\x99t choose to be in a spider\xe2\x80\x99s web. I\xe2\x80\x99ll cut it.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\n      walked straight up to her. \xe2\x80\x9cNow!\xe2\x80\x9d What he had gone up to her to\r\n      do he really did not know. But when he was close, the old\r\n      familiar scent of her clothes suddenly affected him. He put his\r\n      hands on her shoulders and bent forward to kiss her. He kissed\r\n      not her lips, but a little hard line where the lips had been\r\n      drawn in; then his face was pressed away by her hands; he heard\r\n      her say: \xe2\x80\x9cOh! No!\xe2\x80\x9d Shame, compunction, sense of futility flooded\r\n      his whole being, he turned on his heel and went straight out.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER III VISIT TO IRENE\r\n\r\n\r\n      Jolyon found June waiting on the platform at Paddington. She had\r\n      received his telegram while at breakfast. Her abode\xe2\x80\x94a studio and\r\n      two bedrooms in a St. John\xe2\x80\x99s Wood garden\xe2\x80\x94had been selected by her\r\n      for the complete independence which it guaranteed. Unwatched by\r\n      Mrs. Grundy, unhindered by permanent domestics, she could receive\r\n      lame ducks at any hour of day or night, and not seldom had a duck\r\n      without studio of its own made use of June\xe2\x80\x99s. She enjoyed her\r\n      freedom, and possessed herself with a sort of virginal passion;\r\n      the warmth which she would have lavished on Bosinney, and of\r\n      which\xe2\x80\x94given her Forsyte tenacity\xe2\x80\x94he must surely have tired, she\r\n      now expended in championship of the underdogs and budding\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cgeniuses\xe2\x80\x9d of the artistic world. She lived, in fact, to turn\r\n      ducks into the swans she believed they were. The very fervour of\r\n      her protection warped her judgments. But she was loyal and\r\n      liberal; her small eager hand was ever against the oppressions of\r\n      academic and commercial opinion, and though her income was\r\n      considerable, her bank balance was often a minus quantity.\r\n\r\n      She had come to Paddington Station heated in her soul by a visit\r\n      to Eric Cobbley. A miserable Gallery had refused to let that\r\n      straight-haired genius have his one-man show after all. Its\r\n      impudent manager, after visiting his studio, had expressed the\r\n      opinion that it would only be a \xe2\x80\x9cone-horse show from the selling\r\n      point of view.\xe2\x80\x9d This crowning example of commercial cowardice\r\n      towards her favourite lame duck\xe2\x80\x94and he so hard up, with a wife\r\n      and two children, that he had caused her account to be\r\n      overdrawn\xe2\x80\x94was still making the blood glow in her small, resolute\r\n      face, and her red-gold hair to shine more than ever. She gave her\r\n      father a hug, and got into a cab with him, having as many fish to\r\n      fry with him as he with her. It became at once a question which\r\n      would fry them first.\r\n\r\n      Jolyon had reached the words: \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear, I want you to come with\r\n      me,\xe2\x80\x9d when, glancing at her face, he perceived by her blue eyes\r\n      moving from side to side\xe2\x80\x94like the tail of a preoccupied cat\xe2\x80\x94that\r\n      she was not attending. \xe2\x80\x9cDad, is it true that I absolutely can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      get at any of my money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOnly the income, fortunately, my love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHow perfectly beastly! Can\xe2\x80\x99t it be done somehow? There must be a\r\n      way. I know I could buy a small Gallery for ten thousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cA small Gallery,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9cseems a modest desire. But\r\n      your grandfather foresaw it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d cried June vigorously, \xe2\x80\x9cthat all this care about money\r\n      is awful, when there\xe2\x80\x99s so much genius in the world simply crushed\r\n      out for want of a little. I shall never marry and have children;\r\n      why shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I be able to do some good instead of having it all\r\n      tied up in case of things which will never come off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOur name is Forsyte, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Jolyon in the ironical\r\n      voice to which his impetuous daughter had never quite grown\r\n      accustomed; \xe2\x80\x9cand Forsytes, you know, are people who so settle\r\n      their property that their grandchildren, in case they should die\r\n      before their parents, have to make wills leaving the property\r\n      that will only come to themselves when their parents die. Do you\r\n      follow that? Nor do I, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a fact, anyway; we live by the\r\n      principle that so long as there is a possibility of keeping\r\n      wealth in the family it must not go out; if you die unmarried,\r\n      your money goes to Jolly and Holly and their children if they\r\n      marry. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t it pleasant to know that whatever you do you can\r\n      none of you be destitute?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cBut can\xe2\x80\x99t I borrow the money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon shook his head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou could rent a Gallery, no doubt, if\r\n      you could manage it out of your income.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      June uttered a contemptuous sound.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes; and have no income left to help anybody with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear child,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9cwouldn\xe2\x80\x99t it come to the same\r\n      thing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said June shrewdly, \xe2\x80\x9cI could buy for ten thousand; that\r\n      would only be four hundred a year. I could make\r\n      Eric Cobbley\xe2\x80\x99s name in no time, and ever so many others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNames worth making make themselves in time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhen they\xe2\x80\x99re dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever know anybody living, my dear, improved by having\r\n      his name made?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes, you,\xe2\x80\x9d said June, pressing his arm.\r\n\r\n      Jolyon started. \xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. \xe2\x80\x9cOh! Splendidly situated, I\r\n      suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cJust off Cork Street.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Jolyon, \xe2\x80\x9cI knew it was just off somewhere. I\r\n      want you to come with me and see her. Soames is after her again.\r\n      She might be safer if we could give her asylum somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      The word asylum, which he had used by chance, was of all most\r\n      calculated to rouse June\xe2\x80\x99s interest.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIrene! I haven\xe2\x80\x99t seen her since! Of course!
