It was a new-fangled way of\r\n      going about things, and he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know! But he gave Winifred a\r\n      cheque, saying:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI expect you\xe2\x80\x99ll have a lot of expense. That\xe2\x80\x99s a new hat you\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\n      got on. Why doesn\xe2\x80\x99t Val come and see us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Winifred promised to bring him to dinner soon. And, going home,\r\n      she sought her bedroom where she could be alone. Now that her\r\n      husband had been ordered back into her custody with a view to\r\n      putting him away from her for ever, she would try once more to\r\n      find out from her sore and lonely heart what she really wanted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER VIII THE CHALLENGE\r\n\r\n\r\n      The morning had been misty, verging on frost, but the sun came\r\n      out while Val was jogging towards the Roehampton Gate, whence he\r\n      would canter on to the usual tryst. His spirits were rising\r\n      rapidly. There had been nothing so very terrible in the morning\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      proceedings beyond the general disgrace of violated privacy. \xe2\x80\x9cIf\r\n      we were engaged!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat happens wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\n      felt, indeed, like human society, which kicks and clamours at the\r\n      results of matrimony, and hastens to get married. And he galloped\r\n      over the winter-dried grass of Richmond Park, fearing to be late.\r\n      But again he was alone at the trysting spot, and this second\r\n      defection on the part of Holly upset him dreadfully. He could not\r\n      go back without seeing her to-day! Emerging from the Park, he\r\n      proceeded towards Robin Hill. He could not make up his mind for\r\n      whom to ask. Suppose her father were back, or her sister or\r\n      brother were in! He decided to gamble, and ask for them all\r\n      first, so that if he were in luck and they were not there, it\r\n      would be quite natural in the end to ask for Holly; while if any\r\n      of them _were_ in\xe2\x80\x94an \xe2\x80\x9cexcuse for a ride\xe2\x80\x9d must be his saving\r\n      grace.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOnly Miss Holly is in, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! thanks. Might I take my horse round to the stables? And\r\n      would you say\xe2\x80\x94her cousin, Mr. Val Dartie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      When he returned she was in the hall, very flushed and shy. She\r\n      led him to the far end, and they sat down on a wide window-seat.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been awfully anxious,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\n      matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cJolly knows about our riding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cIs he in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo; but I expect he will be soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThen!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Val, and diving forward, he seized her hand. She\r\n      tried to withdraw it, failed, gave up the attempt, and looked at\r\n      him wistfully.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cFirst of all,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI want to tell you something about my\r\n      family. My Dad, you know, isn\xe2\x80\x99t altogether\xe2\x80\x94I mean, he\xe2\x80\x99s left my\r\n      mother and they\xe2\x80\x99re trying to divorce him; so they\xe2\x80\x99ve ordered him\r\n      to come back, you see. You\xe2\x80\x99ll see that in the paper to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Her eyes deepened in colour and fearful interest; her hand\r\n      squeezed his. But the gambler in Val was roused now, and he\r\n      hurried on:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOf course there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing very much at present, but there will\r\n      be, I expect, before it\xe2\x80\x99s over; divorce suits are beastly, you\r\n      know. I wanted to tell you, because\xe2\x80\x94because\xe2\x80\x94you ought to\r\n      know\xe2\x80\x94if\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and he began to stammer, gazing at her troubled eyes,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cif\xe2\x80\x94if you\xe2\x80\x99re going to be a darling and love me, Holly. I love\r\n      you\xe2\x80\x94ever so; and I want to be engaged.\xe2\x80\x9d He had done it in a\r\n      manner so inadequate that he could have punched his own head; and\r\n      dropping on his knees, he tried to get nearer to that soft,\r\n      troubled face. \xe2\x80\x9cYou do love me\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you? If you don\xe2\x80\x99t I....\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      There was a moment of silence and suspense, so awful that he\r\n      could hear the sound of a mowing-machine far out on the lawn\r\n      pretending there was grass to cut. Then she swayed forward; her\r\n      free hand touched his hair, and he gasped: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Holly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Her answer was very soft: \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Val!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      He had dreamed of this moment, but always in an imperative mood,\r\n      as the masterful young lover, and now he felt humble, touched,\r\n      trembly. He was afraid to stir off his knees lest he should break\r\n      the spell; lest, if he did, she should shrink and deny her own\r\n      surrender\xe2\x80\x94so tremulous was she in his grasp, with her eyelids\r\n      closed and his lips nearing them. Her eyes opened, seemed to swim\r\n      a little; he pressed his lips to hers. Suddenly he sprang up;\r\n      there had been footsteps, a sort of startled grunt. He looked\r\n      round. No one! But the long curtains which barred off the outer\r\n      hall were quivering.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cMy God! Who was that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly too was on her feet.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cJolly, I expect,\xe2\x80\x9d she whispered.\r\n\r\n      Val clenched fists and resolution.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care a bit now we\xe2\x80\x99re engaged,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n      striding towards the curtains, he drew them aside. There at the\r\n      fireplace in the hall stood Jolly, with his back elaborately\r\n      turned. Val went forward. Jolly faced round on him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon for hearing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n      With the best intentions in the world, Val could not help\r\n      admiring him at that moment; his face was clear, his voice quiet,\r\n      he looked somehow distinguished, as if acting up to principle.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d Val said abruptly, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s nothing to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly; \xe2\x80\x9cyou come this way,\xe2\x80\x9d and he crossed the hall.\r\n      Val followed. At the study door he felt a touch on his arm;\r\n      Holly\xe2\x80\x99s voice said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m coming too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Holly.\r\n\r\n      Jolly opened the door, and they all three went in. Once in the\r\n      little room, they stood in a sort of triangle on three corners of\r\n      the worn Turkey carpet; awkwardly upright, not looking at each\r\n      other, quite incapable of seeing any humour in the situation.\r\n\r\n      Val broke the silence.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHolly and I are engaged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly stepped back and leaned against the lintel of the window.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThis is our house,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not going to insult you in it.\r\n      But my father\xe2\x80\x99s away. I\xe2\x80\x99m in charge of my sister. You\xe2\x80\x99ve taken\r\n      advantage of me.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val hotly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI think you did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t meant to, you\xe2\x80\x99d\r\n      have spoken to me, or waited for my father to come back.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThere were reasons,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat reasons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAbout my family\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ve just told her. I wanted her to know before\r\n      things happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly suddenly became less distinguished.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re kids,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand you know you are.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI am _not_ a kid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Val.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re not twenty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI _am_ twenty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOnly just; anyway, I\xe2\x80\x99m as good a man as you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s face crimsoned, then clouded. Some struggle was evidently\r\n      taking place in him; and Val and Holly stared at him, so clearly\r\n      was that struggle marked; they could even hear him breathing.\r\n      Then his face cleared up and became oddly resolute.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI dare you to do what I\xe2\x80\x99m going to\r\n      do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDare me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolly smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cdare you; and I know very well you\r\n      won\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      A stab of misgiving shot through Val; this was riding very blind.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI haven\xe2\x80\x99t forgotten that you\xe2\x80\x99re a fire-eater,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly\r\n      slowly, \xe2\x80\x9cand I think that\xe2\x80\x99s about all you are; or that you called\r\n      me a pro-Boer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val heard a gasp above the sound of his own hard breathing, and\r\n      saw Holly\xe2\x80\x99s face poked a little forward, very pale, with big\r\n      eyes.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d went on Jolly with a sort of smile, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall soon see.\r\n      I\xe2\x80\x99m going to join the Imperial Yeomanry, and I dare you to do the\r\n      same, Mr. Val Dartie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val\xe2\x80\x99s head jerked on its stem. It was like a blow between the\r\n      eyes, so utterly unthought of, so extreme and ugly in the midst\r\n      of his dreaming; and he looked at Holly with eyes grown suddenly,\r\n      touchingly haggard.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cSit down!\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly. \xe2\x80\x9cTake your time! Think it over well.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\n      he himself sat down on the arm of his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s chair.\r\n\r\n      Val did not sit down; he stood with hands thrust deep into his\r\n      breeches\xe2\x80\x99 pockets\xe2\x80\x94hands clenched and quivering. The full\r\n      awfulness of this decision one way or the other knocked at his\r\n      mind with double knocks as of an angry postman. If he did not\r\n      take that \xe2\x80\x9cdare\xe2\x80\x9d he was disgraced in Holly\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, and in the\r\n      eyes of that young enemy, her brute of a brother. Yet if he took\r\n      it, ah! then all would vanish\xe2\x80\x94her face, her eyes, her hair, her\r\n      kisses just begun!\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTake your time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly again; \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be unfair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      And they both looked at Holly. She had recoiled against the\r\n      bookshelves reaching to the ceiling; her dark head leaned against\r\n      Gibbon\xe2\x80\x99s _Roman Empire_, her eyes in a sort of soft grey agony\r\n      were fixed on Val. And he, who had not much gift of insight, had\r\n      suddenly a gleam of vision. She would be proud of her\r\n      brother\xe2\x80\x94that enemy! She would be ashamed of him! His hands came\r\n      out of his pockets as if lifted by a spring.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right!\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Holly\xe2\x80\x99s face\xe2\x80\x94oh! it was queer! He saw her flush, start forward.\r\n      He had done the right thing\xe2\x80\x94her face was shining with wistful\r\n      admiration. Jolly stood up and made a little bow as who should\r\n      say: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve passed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cTo-morrow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\xe2\x80\x99ll go together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Recovering from the impetus which had carried him to that\r\n      decision, Val looked at him maliciously from under his lashes.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cone to you. I shall have to join\xe2\x80\x94but\r\n      I\xe2\x80\x99ll get back on you somehow.\xe2\x80\x9d And he said with dignity: \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\n      be ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll meet at the main Recruiting Office, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolly, \xe2\x80\x9cat\r\n      twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d And, opening the window, he went out on to the\r\n      terrace, conforming to the creed which had made him retire when\r\n      he surprised them in the hall.\r\n\r\n      The confusion in the mind of Val thus left alone with her for\r\n      whom he had paid this sudden price was extreme. The mood of\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cshowing-off\xe2\x80\x9d was still, however, uppermost. One must do the\r\n      wretched thing with an air.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe shall get plenty of riding and shooting, anyway,\xe2\x80\x9d he said;\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s one comfort.\xe2\x80\x9d And it gave him a sort of grim pleasure to\r\n      hear the sigh which seemed to come from the bottom of her heart.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cOh! the war\xe2\x80\x99ll soon be over,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps we shan\xe2\x80\x99t even\r\n      have to go out. I don\xe2\x80\x99t care, except for you.\xe2\x80\x9d He would be out of\r\n      the way of that beastly divorce. It was an ill-wind! He felt her\r\n      warm hand slip into his. Jolly thought he had stopped their\r\n      loving each other, did he? He held her tightly round the waist,\r\n      looking at her softly through his lashes, smiling to cheer her\r\n      up, promising to come down and see her soon, feeling somehow six\r\n      inches taller and much more in command of her than he had ever\r\n      dared feel before. Many times he kissed her before he mounted and\r\n      rode back to town. So, swiftly, on the least provocation, does\r\n      the possessive instinct flourish and grow.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER IX DINNER AT JAMES\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\r\n      Dinner parties were not now given at James\xe2\x80\x99 in Park Lane\xe2\x80\x94to every\r\n      house the moment comes when Master or Mistress is no longer \xe2\x80\x9cup\r\n      to it\xe2\x80\x9d. no more can nine courses be served to twenty mouths above\r\n      twenty fine white expanses; nor does the household cat any longer\r\n      wonder why she is suddenly shut up.\r\n\r\n      So with something like excitement Emily\xe2\x80\x94who at seventy would\r\n      still have liked a little feast and fashion now and then\xe2\x80\x94ordered\r\n      dinner for six instead of two, herself wrote a number of foreign\r\n      words on cards, and arranged the flowers\xe2\x80\x94mimosa from the Riviera,\r\n      and white Roman hyacinths not from Rome. There would only be, of\r\n      course, James and herself, Soames, Winifred, Val, and Imogen\xe2\x80\x94but\r\n      she liked to pretend a little and dally in imagination with the\r\n      glory of the past. She so dressed herself that James remarked:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you putting on that thing for? You\xe2\x80\x99ll catch cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      But Emily knew that the necks of women are protected by love of\r\n      shining, unto fourscore years, and she only answered:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLet me put you on one of those dickies I got you, James; then\r\n      you\xe2\x80\x99ll only have to change your trousers, and put on your velvet\r\n      coat, and there you\xe2\x80\x99ll be. Val likes you to look nice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cDicky!\xe2\x80\x9d said James. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re always wasting your money on\r\n      something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      But he suffered the change to be made till his neck also shone,\r\n      murmuring vaguely:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s an extravagant chap, I\xe2\x80\x99m afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      A little brighter in the eye, with rather more colour than usual\r\n      in his cheeks, he took his seat in the drawing-room to wait for\r\n      the sound of the front-door bell.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve made it a proper dinner party,\xe2\x80\x9d Emily said comfortably; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\n      thought it would be good practice for Imogen\xe2\x80\x94she must get used to\r\n      it now she\xe2\x80\x99s coming out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      James uttered an indeterminate sound, thinking of Imogen as she\r\n      used to climb about his knee or pull Christmas crackers with him.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll be pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cI shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cShe _is_ pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emily; \xe2\x80\x9cshe ought to make a good match.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThere you go,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured James; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99d much better stay at home\r\n      and look after her mother.\xe2\x80\x9d A second Dartie carrying off his\r\n      pretty granddaughter would finish him! He had never quite\r\n      forgiven Emily for having been as much taken in by Montague\r\n      Dartie as he himself had been.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhere\xe2\x80\x99s Warmson?\xe2\x80\x9d he said suddenly. \xe2\x80\x9cI should like a glass of\r\n      Madeira to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s champagne, James.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      James shook his head. \xe2\x80\x9cNo body,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t get any good\r\n      out of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Emily reached forward on her side of the fire and rang the bell.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour master would like a bottle of Madeira opened, Warmson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d said James, the tips of his ears quivering with\r\n      vehemence, and his eyes fixed on an object seen by him alone.\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLook here, Warmson, you go to the inner cellar, and on the\r\n      middle shelf of the end bin on the left you\xe2\x80\x99ll see seven bottles;\r\n      take the one in the centre, and don\xe2\x80\x99t shake it. It\xe2\x80\x99s the last of\r\n      the Madeira I had from Mr. Jolyon when we came in here\xe2\x80\x94never been\r\n      moved; it ought to be in prime condition still; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know,\r\n      I can\xe2\x80\x99t tell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cVery good, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the withdrawing Warmson.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI was keeping it for our golden wedding,\xe2\x80\x9d said James suddenly,\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cbut I shan\xe2\x80\x99t live three years at my age.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, James,\xe2\x80\x9d said Emily, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t talk like that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI ought to have got it up myself,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured James, \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99ll shake\r\n      it as likely as not.\xe2\x80\x9d And he sank into silent recollection of\r\n      long moments among the open gas-jets, the cobwebs and the good\r\n      smell of wine-soaked corks, which had been appetiser to so many\r\n      feasts. In the wine from that cellar was written the history of\r\n      the forty odd years since he had come to the Park Lane house with\r\n      his young bride, and of the many generations of friends and\r\n      acquaintances who had passed into the unknown; its depleted bins\r\n      preserved the record of family festivity\xe2\x80\x94all the marriages,\r\n      births, deaths of his kith and kin. And when he was gone there it\r\n      would be, and he didn\xe2\x80\x99t know what would become of it. It\xe2\x80\x99d be\r\n      drunk or spoiled, he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wonder!\r\n\r\n      From that deep reverie the entrance of his son dragged him,\r\n      followed very soon by that of Winifred and her two eldest.\r\n\r\n      They went down arm-in-arm\xe2\x80\x94James with Imogen, the debutante,\r\n      because his pretty grandchild cheered him; Soames with Winifred;\r\n      Emily with Val, whose eyes lighting on the oysters brightened.\r\n      This was to be a proper full \xe2\x80\x9cblowout\xe2\x80\x9d with \xe2\x80\x9cfizz\xe2\x80\x9d and port! And\r\n      he felt in need of it, after what he had done that day, as yet\r\n      undivulged. Still, the old boy was drinking Madeira, and\r\n      looking jolly fit! Besides, he ought to be pleased at this\r\n      set-off to the disgrace of the divorce. Besides,\r\n      better to tell his mother in this way than privately, which might\r\n      upset them both! He was sorry for her, but after all one couldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\n      be expected to feel much for others when one had to part from\r\n      Holly.\r\n\r\n      His grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s voice travelled to him thinly. \xe2\x80\x9cVal, try a\r\n      little of the Madeira with your ice. You won\xe2\x80\x99t get that up at\r\n      college.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Val watched the slow liquid filling his glass, the essential oil\r\n      of the old wine glazing the surface; inhaled its aroma, and\r\n      thought: \xe2\x80\x9cNow for it!\xe2\x80\x9d It was a rich moment. We go into camp on Monday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI _say!_\xe2\x80\x9d cried Imogen.\r\n\r\n      All looked at James. He was leaning forward with his hand behind\r\n      his ear.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s he saying? That fellow,\r\n      with his beard and his cursed amused way of speaking\xe2\x80\x94son of the\r\n      old man who had given him the nickname \xe2\x80\x9cMan of Property,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n      bought the fatal house from him. No!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER X DEATH OF THE DOG BALTHASAR\r\n\r\n\r\n      Jolyon, who had crossed from Calais by night, arrived at Robin\r\n      Hill on Sunday morning. He had sent no word beforehand, so walked\r\n      up from the station, entering his domain by the coppice gate.\r\n      Coming to the log seat fashioned out of an old fallen trunk, he\r\n      sat down, first laying his overcoat on it.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLumbago!\xe2\x80\x9d he thought; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s what love ends in at my time of\r\n      life!\xe2\x80\x9d And suddenly Irene seemed very near, just as she had been\r\n      that day of rambling at Fontainebleau when they had sat on a log\r\n      to eat their lunch. Hauntingly near! Odour drawn out of fallen\r\n      leaves by the pale-filtering sunlight soaked his nostrils. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\n      glad it isn\xe2\x80\x99t spring,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought. Up on the lawn above\r\n      the fernery he could see his old dog Balthasar. The animal, whose\r\n      dim eyes took his master for a stranger, was warning the world\r\n      against him. Jolyon gave his special whistle. Even at that\r\n      distance of a hundred yards and more he could see the dawning\r\n      recognition in the obese brown-white body. The old dog got off\r\n      his haunches, and his tail, close-curled over his back, began a\r\n      feeble, excited fluttering; he came waddling forward, gathered\r\n      momentum, and disappeared over the edge of the fernery. Jolyon\r\n      expected to meet him at the wicket gate, but Balthasar was not\r\n      there, and, rather alarmed, he turned into the fernery. On his\r\n      fat side, looking up with eyes already glazing, the old dog lay.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, my poor old man?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jolyon. He stayed for\r\n      some minutes kneeling; with his hand beneath the stiffening head.\r\n      The body was very heavy when he bore it to the top of the field;\r\n      leaves had drifted there, and he strewed it with a covering of\r\n      them; there was no wind, and they would keep him from curious\r\n      eyes until the afternoon. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bury him myself,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought.\r\n      Eighteen years had gone since he first went into the St. John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      Wood house with that tiny puppy in his pocket. Strange that the\r\n      old dog should die just now! Was it an omen? He turned at the\r\n      gate to look back at that russet mound, then went slowly towards\r\n      the house, very choky in the throat.\r\n\r\n      June was at home; she had come down hotfoot on hearing the news\r\n      of Jolly\xe2\x80\x99s enlistment. The atmosphere of his house was strange and\r\n      pocketty when Jolyon came in and told them of the dog Balthasar\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      death. The news had a unifying effect. A link with the past had\r\n      snapped\xe2\x80\x94the dog Balthasar! But to what end\xe2\x80\x94if\r\n      he had to stop short of his own part?\r\n\r\n      And Jolly thought: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s for Holly to let him know about that\r\n      chap. I\xe2\x80\x99d better leave\r\n      well alone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      So they dug on in silence, till Jolyon said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cNow, old man, I think it\xe2\x80\x99s big enough.\xe2\x80\x9d And, resting on their\r\n      spades, they gazed down into the hole where a few leaves had\r\n      drifted already on a sunset wind.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t bear this part of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jolyon suddenly.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cLet me do it, Dad. He never cared much for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Jolyon shook his head.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll lift him very gently, leaves and all. I\xe2\x80\x99d rather not see\r\n      him again. I\xe2\x80\x99ll take his head. Now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      With extreme care they raised the old dog\xe2\x80\x99s body, whose faded tan\r\n      and white showed here and there under the leaves stirred by the\r\n      wind. They laid it, heavy, cold, and unresponsive, in the grave,\r\n      and Jolly spread more leaves over it, while Jolyon, deeply afraid\r\n      to show emotion before his son, began quickly shovelling the\r\n      earth on to that still shape. There went the past! If only there\r\n      were a joyful future to look forward to! It was like stamping\r\n      down earth on one\xe2\x80\x99s own life. They replaced the turf carefully on\r\n      the smooth little mound, and, grateful that they had spared each\r\n      other\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, returned to the house arm-in-arm.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER XI TIMOTHY STAYS THE ROT\r\n\r\n\r\n      On Forsyte \xe2\x80\x99Change news of the enlistment spread fast, together\r\n      with the report that June, not to be outdone, was going to become\r\n      a Red Cross nurse. These events were so extreme, so subversive of\r\n      pure Forsyteism, as to have a binding effect upon the family, and\r\n      Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s was thronged next Sunday afternoon by members trying to\r\n      find out what they thought about it all, and exchange with each\r\n      other a sense of family credit. Giles and Jesse Hayman would no\r\n      longer defend the coast but go to South Africa quite soon; Jolly\r\n      and Val would be following in April; as to June\xe2\x80\x94well, you never\r\n      knew what she would really do.\r\n\r\n      The retirement from Spion Kop and the absence of any good news\r\n      from the seat of war imparted an air of reality to all this,\r\n      clinched in startling fashion by Timothy. The youngest of the old\r\n      Forsytes\xe2\x80\x94scarcely eighty, in fact popularly supposed to resemble\r\n      their father, \xe2\x80\x9cSuperior Dosset,\xe2\x80\x9d even in his best-known\r\n      characteristic of drinking Sherry\xe2\x80\x94had been invisible for so many\r\n      years that he was almost mythical. A long generation had elapsed\r\n      since the risks of a publisher\xe2\x80\x99s business had worked on his\r\n      nerves at the age of forty, so that he had got out with a mere\r\n      thirty-five thousand pounds in the world, and started to make his\r\n      living by careful investment. Putting by every year, at compound\r\n      interest, he had doubled his capital in forty years without\r\n      having once known what it was like to shake in his shoes over\r\n      money matters. He was now putting aside some two thousand a year,\r\n      and, with the care he was taking of himself, expected, so Aunt\r\n      Hester said, to double his capital again before he died. What he\r\n      would do with it then, with his sisters dead and himself dead,\r\n      was often mockingly queried by free spirits such as Francie,\r\n      Euphemia, or young Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99 second, Christopher, whose spirit\r\n      was so free that he had actually said he was going on the stage.\r\n      All admitted, however, that this was best known to Timothy\r\n      himself, and possibly to Soames, who never divulged a secret.\r\n\r\n      Those few Forsytes who had seen him reported a man of thick and\r\n      robust appearance, not very tall, with a brown-red complexion,\r\n      grey hair, and little of the refinement of feature with which\r\n      most of the Forsytes had been endowed by \xe2\x80\x9cSuperior Dosset\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n      wife, a woman of some beauty and a gentle temperament. It was\r\n      known that he had taken surprising interest in the war, sticking\r\n      flags into a map ever since it began, and there was uneasiness as\r\n      to what would happen if the English were driven into the sea,\r\n      when it would be almost impossible for him to put the flags in\r\n      the right places. As to his knowledge of family movements or his\r\n      views about them, little was known, save that Aunt Hester was\r\n      always declaring that he was very upset. It was, then, in the\r\n      nature of a portent when Forsytes, arriving on the Sunday after\r\n      the evacuation of Spion Kop, became conscious, one after the\r\n      other, of a presence seated in the only really comfortable\r\n      armchair, back to the light, concealing the lower part of his\r\n      face with a large hand, and were greeted by the awed voice of\r\n      Aunt Hester:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYour Uncle Timothy, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s greeting to them all was somewhat identical; and\r\n      rather, as it were, passed over by him than expressed:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cHow de do? How de do? \xe2\x80\x99Xcuse me gettin\xe2\x80\x99 up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Francie was present, and Eustace had come in his car; Winifred\r\n      had brought Imogen, breaking the ice of the restitution\r\n      proceedings with the warmth of family appreciation at Val\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n      enlistment; and Marian Tweetyman with the last news of Giles and\r\n      Jesse. These with Aunt Juley and Hester, young Nicholas,\r\n      Euphemia, and\xe2\x80\x94of all people!\xe2\x80\x94George, who had come with Eustace in\r\n      the car, constituted an assembly worthy of the family\xe2\x80\x99s palmiest\r\n      days. There was not one chair vacant in the whole of the little\r\n      drawing-room, and anxiety was felt lest someone else should\r\n      arrive.\r\n\r\n      The constraint caused by Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s presence having worn off a\r\n      little, conversation took a military turn. George asked Aunt\r\n      Juley when she was going out with the Red Cross, almost reducing\r\n      her to a state of gaiety; whereon he turned to Nicholas and said:\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cYoung Nick\xe2\x80\x99s a warrior bold, isn\xe2\x80\x99t he? When\xe2\x80\x99s he going to don\r\n      the wild khaki?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n      Young Nicholas, smiling with a sort of sweet deprecation,\r\n      intimated that of course his mother was very anxious.\r\n\r\n      \xe2\x80\x9cThe Dromios are off, I hear,\xe2\x80\x9d said George, turning to Marian\r\n      Tweetyman; \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall all be there soon. _En avant_, the Forsytes!\r\n      Roll, bowl, or pitch! Then he could show them all where they were.\r\n\r\n      At a sound from Timothy, interpreted as assent, Aunt Hester left\r\n      the room.\r\n\r\n      George pursued his image of the Forsyte advance, addressing\r\n      Timothy as Field Marshal; and Imogen, whom he had noted at once\r\n      for \xe2\x80\x9ca pretty filly,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94as Vivandi\xc3\xa8re; and holding his top hat\r\n      between his knees, he began to beat it with imaginary drumsticks.\r\n      The reception accorded to his fantasy was mixed. All\r\n      laughed\xe2\x80\x94George was licensed; but all felt that the family was\r\n      being \xe2\x80\x9crotted\xe2\x80\x9d; and this seemed to them unnatural, now that it\r\n      was going to give five of its members to the service of the\r\n      Queen. But at present there seems to\r\n      have been nothing very conclusive. The meetings have all been in\r\n      public places, without concealment\xe2\x80\x94restaurants, the Opera, the\r\n      Comique, the Louvre, Luxembourg Gardens, lounge of the hotel, and\r\n      so forth. With Forsyte tenacity Winifred quested for perfection.\r\n      It took her mind off the slowly approaching rite which would give\r\n      her a freedom but doubtfully desired; took her mind, too, off her\r\n      boy and his fast approaching departure for a war from which the\r\n      news remained disquieting.
